Dear Doctor Westgate:

Regarding the account for the Brotherston Electric Co. Time and time again both the engineer and myself tested the Bell Line, sometimes it would work, sometimes it would not. On one occasion the bells responded in the morning, in the afternoon they were entirely out of order. For three or four consecutive days the bells would answer, then would come an interval of one or two days when no response could be obtained.

The fuses were tested time and again, and it was then considered that owing to the dampness between the brick courses, a short circuit had occurred, hence the difficulty of locating the particular trouble.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) S. Middleton
Principal.
Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of April 3rd, (No. not visible) relative to the Bell Electric School, I hold reserves, Jordan, Ont., in which we have our facilities, to meet the expenses amounting to $150.00 incurred by Mr. Brotherston, of the Electric Bell Co., of Ontario, when he visited the school to explain the Electric Bell system which he had installed there. I am now herewith enclosing a copy of his bill from the Electric Bell Co., and it quite clear, I think, that the trouble with the Electric Bell system was due to something more than to "a burnt-out fuse," as Mr. Brotherston seems to have stated.

Our society has discussed this bill, but in view of the explanation given by Mr. Brotherston, and in view of the fact that our society cannot be a fully competent body for this position, I am of the opinion that the amount paid, namely $150.00 should be refunded, and I shall be glad to if you will furnish me with a cheque for said amount.

I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of April 3rd (No. not available) addressed to the Rev. S. Liddleton, Principal of St. Paul's Indian Residential School, Blood Reserve, Cardston, Alta., and in which you state your inability to meet the expenses amounting to $22.35 incurred by Mr. Brotherton, of the Brotherton Electric Co., of Calgary, when he visited the Blood School to examine the electric bell system which was not working satisfactorily, I enclose herewith a copy of a letter from the Principal which makes it quite clear, I think, that the trouble with the electric bell system was due to something more than to "a burnt-out fuse", as Mr. Brotherton appears to have stated.

Our Society has already paid this bill, but in view of the explanation given by the Principal, and in view of the fact that our Society's engineer was a fully competent man for this position, I am of the opinion that the amount paid, namely $22.35 should be refunded, and I shall be obliged if you will furnish me with a cheque for this amount.

I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

FIELD SECRETARY M.S.C.C.
Ottawa, June 16th, 1925.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, enclosing copy of a communication from the Principal of St. Paul's Indian Residential School relative to the account of the Brotherston Electric Co., of Calgary, in examining the electric bell system.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of the Principal's explanation, the Department will pay this account to the amount of $22.35. I have, therefore, to request that you will forward the receipted account, in duplicate, when payment will be made.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Aast. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Dr. Westgate:

With further reference to the question of additional outbuildings to be erected by the Department during this summer. The Indian Agent informed me today that he has received instructions from the Indian Commissioner to proceed with the erection of three buildings for St. Paul's—Piggery, Henery and Implement Shed, but no Farm Instructor's House is to be built this year, at least, so Mr. Faunt said.

In the Department letter of April 6th it states that a sum of $2500.00 has been voted for outbuildings at St. Paul's. These will cost approximately $1200.00, what will be done with the balance of the grant? The Indian Commissioner wrote you on April 28th saying: "I may assure you however that a cottage for the farmer will be built at the Blood School this summer, as well as a henhouse, piggery, implement shed and garage."

I am simply reporting these matters so that you may be fully cognizant of what is being done. If the Farm Instructor's House is not to be built this summer, I would strongly recommend that an outside Dairy and a Utility Building be erected with the balance of the grant. In order to have more money to spend on the actual buildings I am doing all the hauling etc., with the school teams and labour.

Furthermore—Mr. Scott replied to your letter last December stating that the Toilets could be installed in the upper dormitories when needed. Pupils are sleeping in the upper dormitories and there is no provision for toilet accommodation, other than the mere "roughing in" as the pipes were left by the contractors last winter. Would it be possible to bring this matter to the attention of the Department as soon as possible?

Thanking you in anticipation,

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) S. Middleton
Principal.

Dear Sir:-

I have your letter of the 19th instant #103-1-5 informing me that the Reverend Principal of the St. Paul's Indian Residential School has advised the Department that he is co-operating with me in the erection of four outbuildings at the school. This is the first intimation I have had that he is co-operating with me in the erection of these buildings. I have had no communication with him on the matter, further than to say that I was going to put up a henhouse, pigsty, and implement shed.

I have not the plans of the St. Paul School before me, but am I right in saying that they did provide for a dairy? I am not prepared at the present time to recommend a dairy out of the amount set aside for outbuildings.

Sir:-

I am today in receipt of a letter from our Agent on the Blood Reserve in which he deals with various matters in connection with the St. Paul School. He says regarding the roof water which discharges from the down-spouts on to the ground and alongside of the building that he thinks some temporary arrangement by way of plank surface drains should be made to carry this water away from the building as at present it is soaking down under the foundation, which, of course, will eventually cause settlement of the building and cracking of the walls. The Agent has made a suggestion as to how this water may be diverted at a cost of about $75.00 and in order to save unnecessary delay I have ordered him to proceed with the work along the lines suggested by him.

The Agent points out that the windows in the attic of the school are only tacked in temporarily, allowing the rain and snow to blow right through, and that there are several places where you can see right through the roof. I have instructed him to have these matters attended to at once. He tells me that during the recent rains there has been considerable leakage from the tower, the water leaking down to the ground floor where it was caught in tubs. He expresses the opinion that in a windy country this tower was a mistake. There is no doubt about this. There has also been considerable damage done through defective eave-troughing but this matter will be dealt with in a separate letter.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th inst., in which you asked me to make a report regarding the leakage from eave-troughs of above school, giving also an estimate of cost to correct the trouble.

The Reverend Principal (Canon Middleton) conducted me through the building, and I was able to see that in a number of the rooms a considerable quantity of water had penetrated through the walls, and had caused some disfigurement of the plaster. In one room a small area of plaster had become loosened by the water.

The main cause of the admission of water is from the eave-troughs. There has been some leakage from this source ever since the building was completed, but during the latter part of the winter the continued filling of the gutters with ice, and the consequent expansion and contraction caused by the changes of weather has had the effect of bursting many of the soldered places where leak joints in the metal covering occur, which damage was inevitably followed by leakage.

Guttering partly over the brickwork the water thus leaking through the joints in the metal penetrated through the tile and reached the interior plastered surfaces. This condition is inevitable, and will continue, and become worse, until the cause of the trouble is overcome.

The design of the gutter is good and is very suitable for a school building. The framing of it is strong, and it is possible for any person not affected by height and ground to walk with safety along the gutter and remove obstructions, or open the outlets to downspouts, without danger. The reason for the gutter proving leaky is in consequence of the galvanized iron lining contracting and expanding, and bursting the joints. This metal acts as a dam from the gutter 30" up the roof, with 24" of it exposed before meeting the shingles. In other words the unglazed end 24" from the gutter, and there is this metal surface 24" wide all around the roof. In both the metal lining of gutter, and in the metal on the roof itself, there has been bursting of soldered joints. Also, at the lower edge of the roof there is a horizontal leak joint, which also has been coming open in places.

I do not consider it possible to avoid leakage where galvanized iron is used even in the manner described. It has been tried elsewhere, with similar results, and I am told that in some of the Calgary schools exactly the same trouble was experienced with galvanized iron lining in the gutters, but that the trouble was finally overcome by changing the sheet lead lining. I think it would prove a waste of money to try to stop the leakage at St. Paul's school by tinkering with the existing galvanized iron. In this Chinook district, with sudden and extreme changes of weather, roof gutters are subject to unusual strains, and types of gutters that may have proved satisfactory in more equable climates, do not stand the test here.
To remedy the trouble I would recommend that the following be done:

Line the gutters with sheet lead, 1/16" in thickness, weighing 4 lbs. per sq. ft., and extend the metal 8" up on the roof boarding and shingle down to the edge of the gutter. In this manner the joint could be made leak-proof. The lead is somewhat elastic in its nature and is capable of adjusting itself to weather changes without bursting joints. In fact the solder becomes fused with the lead, and there is practically no joint to open. The only objection to this method is its cost. There are 520 lin. ft. of gutter to this building, and it would take a strip of lead 42" wide to line the gutter with sufficient overlap, which figures at 1820 sq. ft. of lead, weighing 7360 lbs. at 4 lbs. per sq. ft.

**DETAIL OF COST OF LEAD LINING & SHINGLING**

| Item                                      | Cost   |
|-------------------------------------------|--------|
| 11 M Shingles @ $7.00 per M               | 77.00  |
| 10 lbs. Shingle Nails @ 9¢ per lb.        | 4.50   |
| Labour shingling along edge of roof       | 35.00  |
| Staining shingles, labor & material       | 35.00  |
| Lead lining, labour and material, as per estimate of P.W. Flatt, Cardston | 1750.00 |
| **Total**                                 | **1901.50** |

Before regarding the above estimate as a minimum, I would get outside quotations on the lead lining and labour of placing it.

Another method of avoiding admission of water to the building from the eave troughs would be to take down the present eave trough, continue the rafters about 1 ft. beyond exterior outside wall line, build out look-outs from the ceiling joists to make a framework with the extended rafters, with soffit and fascia, and attach an oval gal. iron eave-trough to fascia. This method would require roof sheeting on the extended rafters, and shingle along edge of gutter, but would not be so satisfactory as the first, although it would cause some dismemberment to the building occasioned by scaffolding cut from the windows, and its appearance would not be so good. The gal. iron gutters would not be so lasting, and would be difficult to reach for cleaning-out or repairs. However, should they prove leaky, the water would drop beyond the wall-line, and could not reach the interior of the building in the manner at present occurring. The cost of this method would be about as follows:

**DETAIL OF COST OF EXTENDING ROOF & NEW GUTTER.**

| Item                                      | Cost   |
|-------------------------------------------|--------|
| Roof sheeting and Rafter Extensions       | 40.00  |
| 14 M Shingles @ $7.00 per M              | 98.00  |
| Shingle Nails, 60 lbs. @ 9¢ per lb.      | 5.40   |
| Labour Shingling                          | 45.00  |
| Shingle Stain, labour & material          | 40.00  |
| Removing old eave framing & making good; |        |
| 520' @ $1.75 per lin.ft.                 | 910.00 |
| Oval Gal. Iron Gutter, 16" girth, with    |        |
| roof straps, 520' @ 30¢ per ft.          | 156.00 |
| Extensions to downspouts, elbows, etc.    | 25.00  |
| **Total**                                 | **1319.40** |

The latter method would get us away from leakage into building from the eave troughs, but it would not be so satisfactory, nor look as well as the first method, but would have the advantage of some saving in cost.
Should the first method suggested for correcting the trouble be adopted, it would cause practically no disturbance to the school. There will be no alteration in the design of the gutter nor change in the appearance of the building, besides which there need be no more fear of leakage of water into the building from the suave-troughs. A good reliable sheet-metal man would give several years' guarantee from leaks. It would be unfair to consider the cost of the lead lining in the light of an upkeep expense, for if this lining had been specified in the first place, the contractors' figure would have been proportionately higher. The building will have an added value if this work is done.

I might mention that Mr. D.D. Smith, of Smith Bros. & Wilson, Ltd., was here yesterday, and, at my request he accompanied me to St. Paul's School, and I conferred with him as to the best and cheapest manner of permanently correcting the suave-trough trouble, and the proposals I have made represent our joint opinion, made after a careful examination of the existing conditions.

I would like to emphasize the importance of early attention being given to the matter. Every rain we get is causing further damage to the building, and, as stated before, the trouble will get worse until corrected. It is doubly important that the necessary work be done before the snow and ice of the coming winter aggravate an already serious condition.

Outbuildings:

The implement shed and garage had already been arranged for and the carpenters had it about completed at the time of my visit. The chicken house was also practically completed. I, however, arranged for the following buildings,

Root cellar

$2500.00 was allowed for these outbuildings by the Department and I have seen to it that this amount will not be exceeded in the erection of the buildings above mentioned. The school is doing all the hauling of the material, and the excavating for the root cellar, but the work of erecting the buildings is being done by Mr. Butcher as foreman. This man has worked on the reserve off and on for a number of years, and I have always found his work very satisfactory. When the above mentioned buildings are completed, which will be in a very short time, they will fully meet the requirements of the school for the present time, and will be quite in keeping with the institution. The only other building mentioned by the Principal was a combination ice house and dairy building. This, of course, could not be considered this year, as it could not be built out of the appropriation.

The building
The building that Mr. Middleton has in mind for this purpose would cost in the neighbourhood of at least twelve or thirteen hundred dollars. I do not consider, however, that there is any great urgency for this building, as a dairy space was provided in the school, which, however, is not altogether satisfactory. If it is thought advisable to supply the school with the above mentioned building an amount should be placed in the Estimates this year to provide for same, so that the work can be gone on with next Spring. The matter of a Farming Instructor's house for next year was also brought to my attention, and I understand that the church authorities are asking to have an item placed in the Estimates to provide for this expenditure.

School Attendance:

The matter of school attendance was brought to my attention, as there are only about one hundred children in the school at the present time, and they have accommodation in the institution for an additional twenty-five. Mr. Middleton stated that there were a number of children on the reserve who were not attending school. I went into this matter with the Agent and he states that he has seen all the Indians who have children of school age with a view of having them entered in the St. Paul's School, and they have refused to send their children there on the grounds that they intend to send them to the new R.C.School as soon as it opens, and as the parents have the option of sending their children to whatever school.
whatever school they choose, they evidently are within their rights, and from my point of view I cannot see that anything further can be done until the Roman Catholic School is opened. As soon as it is, I think the school regulations should be enforced to the limit in this Agency, as with two new schools on the reserve, which are up-to-date in every way, there will be no excuse for the Indians keeping their children at home, as according to the location of these schools it will be quite convenient for the parents to visit their children quite frequently, and I think it would be well for the Department to issue instructions to the Agent along the lines I have suggested.

Mr. Scott,

Dear Canon:

I enclose herewith a tender from Messrs. Snyder & Co. of Calgary, for the alteration of the power transmission in the machinery room of your school. In accordance with the request made by your engineer, said tender being for £180.00.

Your engineer informs me that the proposed change would effect a saving in his time of 35 hours per week, besides wear and tear of machinery, and would also result in a very appreciable saving of gasoline.

As at present arranged, the power plant is in use for running laundry machines during a large part of Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays, during which time he is unable to pump. As the laundry machines do not nearly use the full power of the engine it means that the engineer is unable to use the surplus power for pumping at the same time that the laundry countershaft is running, but must pump afterwards. By making the proposed change the pumping and the operation of the laundry machines could be carried on simultaneously, or, through the medium of a clutch on the lineshaft, the pumping could be done separately, without running the laundry shafting.

I discussed the matter fully with your engineer, and I have no hesitation in recommending the change, in the interests of economy. As Mr. Snyder installed the machinery he is familiar with the conditions existing, and could be depended on to carry out the change in a satisfactory manner. I consider the price he has quoted a reasonable one.

Yours very truly,

(Signed) E. Gardner Smith,
Inspector of Construction.

Dear Sir,

Re St. Paul's Indian School, Cardston.

We have to report the completion of our contract at the above building, and the taking over of the works by the Inspector, Mr. E. Gardner Smith, as from December 20th.

In making up the final accounts, there were discussed a number of items of expense and cost allowances for which we expect to receive payment, but which Mr. Smith said he had no authority to handle although some of them are specifically mentioned in the contract and in the list of deductions made at the time the contract was revised. A statement was therefore prepared covering all work with which Mr. Smith had authority to deal, and we received his certificate covering the account rendered to him. Mr. Smith issued this certificate as the final one, but as it does not cover items allowed for in the contract, and others which have been the subject of correspondence, which Mr. Smith stated he had no authority to handle, we do not regard it as the final settlement.

The matters we have reference to are as follows:

- Increased Sales Tax.
- Increased bricklayers wages.
- Allowance of $500.00 for Sundries, Revision of Main entrance and residence porches.
- Brick piers built into tile walls, to carry steel.
- Wood beams in residence and laundry in connection with revision of steel price.
- Beam furring under metal ceilings.
- Cost of Water Tower, owing to late date of construction.
- Heating of building owing to general delay caused by tower construction.
- Location of installation of fan in laundry.
- Chimney built in Laundry.
We understand that Mr. Smith's reluctance to pass on these matters is solely due to his regarding them as being beyond his authority, although he is fully in agreement with us that they deserve your favourable consideration.

The first two listed arose as a result of the delay in proceeding with the work owing to questions of the site.

The allowance of $500.00 was made to cover Sundries, Revision of Main Entrance and Residence Porch. We were not able during the course of the work to make this saving. The Main Entrance was changed from stone to brick, around the arch, but a full credit was given for all the stone omitted and this was replaced by expensive pier and arch brickwork which was an addition to the amount of brickwork on the contract drawings for which we received no allowance, so that the small saving made on the residence porch was used up again in the cost of brickwork substituted for stone on the main entrance.

On the question of effecting a general saving, we used up anything which might have gone toward this $500.00 allowance by building an enlarged coal room, with reinforced concrete slab roof at grade level, at a cost to us of about $600.00. In connection with this fuel room, Mr. Smith knows from his observation of the work that we are sacrificing about $150.00 to put in the fuel room, so that there is no question of having made savings to offset the $500.00 allowed in deductions from the contract.

While the work was in progress, Mr. Smith, undoubtedly with the interest of the building and good construction at heart, was so anxious to maintain the highest possible standard on a job already cheapened to the limit of safety, that it was impossible to find any other way to make any savings to apply on the amount deducted for sundries.

The brick piers built into tile walls, and wood posts and beams in residence and laundry in connection with credit on steel, have already been the subject of correspondence but have not been brought to a settlement.

There arose the question of beam furring which was not covered by the figures given you on the ceiling boards. This was put in where required, but Mr. Smith had no way of dealing with it.

Owing to the order to proceed with erection of water tower being so long delayed, its construction had to be carried out mainly in bad weather, which added a great deal to its cost, so much so that both we and our subcontractors
for plumbing and heating, lost money on this piece of work, due solely to delays for which we were not responsible which ran the work into impossible weather conditions.

Another feature in connection with the tower construction was the fact that we were forced to hold up the general progress on contract work of the building in order to be able to hold some of our men for work on the tower when material for it arrived from the Coast. This so affected general progress that we were delayed at least six weeks on the general clean up of the work, and subject to the added overhead for that period, as well as the cost of heating the building when the cold weather made it necessary.

Mr. Smith will verify these statements about delay, and we are therefore preparing a statement on the tower construction on a time and material basis, as well as for our costs on heating, and ask your favourable consideration on this method of billing for the work.

We are preparing accounts on all the work mentioned in this letter, and these will be forwarded to you as soon as possible. In the meantime will you kindly have the enclosed certificate paid, and our tender deposit released to us, as soon as possible. In the matter of tender deposit, will you please hold sufficient of the Victory Bonds deposited in connection with this contract, to make a ten per cent deposit on account of the Kamloops contract, and return the balance to us together with the cash deposit which was made at the time our tender on Kamloops was submitted.

Wishing you the Compliments of the Season, and thanking you for your kind cooperation throughout the work, we are,

Yours very truly,

CLAYDON COMPANY LIMITED.

January Twenty Sixth,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

re St. Paul's Indian School, Cardston.

When we wrote the Department on December 29th, 1924, we intimated that we had other items which we wished to have considered, but regret that a peculiar combination of circumstances have prevented us from bringing the details to your notice before this time.

We could not make up the statement at the time we wrote as the additional guys for the water tower, ordered by Mr. Smith, were not finished. Owing to severe weather conditions it was some considerable time later that the work was completed. Then early last year the new top was put on the septic tank, and this was followed by a long period of correspondence with Mr. Smith about gutters, and prices of work on them. We thought we would bring matters to a conclusion when all of the above were disposed of, and this is our earliest opportunity.

Referring to our letter of December 29th, 1924, you will note that we mentioned increased sales tax. This consideration was promised to us at the time the contract was revised. Tax was then 4½¢, and was raised to 6½¢, but before we bought much material was lowered to 5½¢, so the actual difference came down to 1½¢. We therefore decided not to raise the question further.

The other items we refer to are in the same order as they appear in our letter, and on the enclosed account.

No. 3. Increased bricklayers' wages.

This matter was raised when the contract was revised and we were promised the increase would be paid if it went into effect. The prevailing wage when the work was figured in...
October 1923 was $1.15 per hour. In June 1924, it was raised to $1.25, making a difference of 10¢ per hour as charged.

No. 2. Item No. 13 on contract revisions.
This we found could not be saved, as any saving effected was used by Mr. Smith to offset cost of the enlarged cool room.

No. 3. Brick piers etc.
These were not called for in contract, but were ordered by Mr. Smith.

No. 4. Wood Posts etc.
We gave Mr. Orr credit for steel omitted in good faith, but failed to deduct from such credit cost of wood beams required to take their place, and further we were unable to secure from our subcontractors as large a credit as the one we made to the Department. We now ask that this item be allowed us.

No. 5. Beams for framing.
Ordered by Mr. Smith, but not specified, same item was paid for at Edmonton.

No. 6. Costs due to delay.
This cost was all thrust upon us by continued delay in awarding contract for water supply system. Our quotations on the work were given in the expectation that it could be done concurrently with the contract work. Unfortunately the order came too late, and coupled with a series of severe storms during which the tower work could not be carried on, and then the freeze up, we were placed in a very awkward position. We had to lay off two thirds of our men on the school work in order to have the remainder available to build water tower and erect the tank when materials arrived. Costs as shown were involved and we trust that the Department will accept responsibility. The circumstances which caused the extra cost were unavoidable.

No. 7. Fan in Laundry.
This item was necessary and not specified.

No. 8. Building chimney in Laundry.
Ordered by Mr. Smith who thought it was included in revision of contract. We have no record of this being done.
No. 9. Guys on water tower.
Ordered by Mr. Smith as additional safeguard against very high wind peculiar to locality.

No. 10 & 11.
This work was done by a man we left at Cardston to attend to any items required, at the request of Mr. Smith or Canon Middleton. We think both these items are covered by conditions outside of our contract.

No. 12. Septic tank roof.
Tank as originally built was according to design, but new wooden top was found to be necessary.

No. 13. Visit to Ottawa.
Arranged for when contract was revised.

In addition to the above items we found many pieces of work on which we gave reduced prices when revising amount of contract, but on which we were unable to save the reduction given, particularly on face brick, reduction of wall thickness, and painting. As we gave definite figures on the revision, we are not going back on them. We trust however, your cooperation will be given in passing the items asked for.

Yours very truly,

We do not mean that our plant is so complicated that it needs a qualified engineer to look after it but in this case he is a man that has never had any connections whatever or experience with gasoline engines and therefore not in a position to readily put right any small or minor troubles which are always cropping up with a gasoline engine.

We want to see these plants giving satisfaction and we certainly are going to give all the service possible which we can but if the different organizations which are looking after these plants will not place a man who has had some experience in charge, they cannot expect to get results with any equipment.

The plants of similar type which were placed in your Edmonton School have a competent man in charge, the result being they have never had any trouble whatever since installation was made. Trusting you will give this your immediate and fair consideration, we are,

Dear Sir:

Regarding the Invoice of Snyder & Co. of Calgary, of $182.50, dated Feb. 1st, for work done at the above school, the particulars are as follows:

Previously the laundry line shaft was continuous, and passed through into the machinery room, to further side of said room, all in one length. It was then impossible to do pumping while the laundry machinery was running, there being no connection from said countershaft to pump pulley. Pumping was done direct from engine pulley by belt to pump pulley. To run the laundry machinery it was necessary to stop pump, remove belt, and put on another belt to reach from engine pulley to pulley on line shaft.

The change in transmission called for cutting the line shaft just inside the machinery room, at which point a friction clutch has been installed. Also the pump has been changed from centre drive to side drive. An extra pulley has been put on line shaft, and extra belting and attachments supplied.

It is now possible to either pump separately, or while the laundry machinery is running. This feature means an important saving in gasoline, wear-and-tear, etc., and also a considerable saving in the engineer's time.

The work has been properly performed, and the change is much appreciated.

Dear Sir:

On the completion of the new R.C.School, Blood Reserve, I asked the Indian Agent, Mr. Faunt, to notify the Provincial Department of Public Works that there were two heating boilers and one high-pressure laundry boiler that required inspection under Provincial regulations. As the regular boiler inspector for this district was absent in Ontario the Department sent an inspector from Calgary. Owing to the fact that the boilers at St. Paul's school had not been inspected for considerably over a year, having gone longer without inspection than is allowed by law, the boiler inspector visited that school too, and inspected the three boilers there. Altogether 6 boilers were inspected.

It has been my practice to have inspection made of steam heating plants previous to accepting the building from the contractors. Also, I aim at having the inspection made while the heating contractor is on the job, so that any changes which the boiler inspector may ask for can be carried out. Several changes were asked for here, which have been attended to, with the exception of different safety valves which have been ordered but have not yet come.

The charge of $14.00 per day is made up thus: boiler-inspector's time, $10 per day, subsistence allowance $4.00 per day. The cost of inspection came higher in consequence of the absence from the district of the regular inspector, and the higher cost of getting one from a more distant territory.

Sir:-

Acting under instructions from Mr. M. Christianson Inspector of Indian Agencies, I have attended to the matter of shortage of water at St. Paul's School.

The shortage was caused by the falling of the water-level in the well, but at first I could not be sure of this, as there was a chance that the failure to pump sufficient water might be the result of the wearing of the leathers on the working barrel, especially as the original leathers had never been renewed. I therefore had new leathers installed, at a cost of $15.30.

It was then found that the conditions were practically the same, and there was no help for it but to lower the cylinder to a point below the working level of the water. This called for drawing all the well piping, and adding 60' of 4" P&H gal. piping, and the same length of ash sucker rods, for which we had received a quotation from Mr. Flett of $182.00.

Ample water was obtained in consequence of the lowering of the cylinder, but the noise of the pumping from the lower level made a tremendous pounding noise all through the building. To overcome this feature it became necessary to install a new air chamber, and alter an existing valve at a cost of $46.64, as shown on Mr. Flett's bill.

The pumping system is now working perfectly and silently, and an abundance of water is being obtained.

I enclose herewith Mr. Flett's bills for $15.30 and $228.64, which cover all the work and materials supplied by him in connection with the pumping plant at this school.

I have the honour to be, Sir

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) E. Gardner Smith
Inspector of Construction.

Sir:

I recently received a letter from the Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, Field Secretary of the M.S.C.C., stating that the engine at the St. Paul's school on the Blood reserve is not sufficiently powerful for the work it is expected to do in connection with the light and water systems and asks that it may be replaced by more powerful equipment and the one now in use could be installed in the new school being erected on the Peigan reserve.

It will be remembered that the plant now at St. Paul's school was transferred from the Crowfoot school on the Blackfoot reserve when the Power Company carried its line through the reserve and we decided to secure our power from that source. It is described as a 6 K.W. plant and I thought it would be large enough to do the work at St. Paul's. You will also remember that we have a 9 K.W. plant at the R.C. school on the Blood reserve, consisting of a parallel 3 K.W. and 6 K.W., bought from the R.A. Lister & Company (Canada) Ltd.

When recently on the Blood reserve Mr. Christianson did hear the complaint that the St. Paul's engine was not powerful enough and it is possible that we should install there a larger plant like the one at the R.C. school. I think possibly that the St. Paul's school authorities think that their school should be equipped similarly to the R.C. school and may be ever ready to condemn the equipment now in use. We can duplicate the equipment at the R.C. school at St. Paul's at a price installed of $5375.00. This figure I have obtained from the Company's Agent in Winnipeg and I shall be glad to know if the Department would consider the change suggested. In making the suggestion Rev. Dr. Westgate says, "If the new engine could be purchased and installed at St. Paul's school in the near future, it would save our Society considerable money for gasoline and the Principal and Engineer much anxiety."

The Secretary

Sir,

On the 20th ult., I wrote you in regard to a complaint that the plant installed at St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve is not sufficiently powerful for the work it is expected to do in connection with the light and water systems. I have just received a report from the R.A. Lister & Company Ltd., of Winnipeg, in regard to this plant. They say it is running approximately fifteen hours a day and is too small for the job owing to the fact that there is not sufficient power to do the pumping work and supply their lights at the same time at night; consequently, the engine has to run for a long period during the day to pump water which a larger plant could do at night. The lighting load makes a demand of 50 amperes, which is practically the full capacity of the plant.

It seems to me that if the plant they now have will carry the lighting load, the pumping could be done by the installation of an engine for the purpose. I have procured particulars from the Airplane-Morse Company of Canada, Ltd., of two engines. One of 1½ H.P. will cost only $79.05 at Regina and occupy a space of 2' 6" by 2'. A 3 H.P. engine would be preferable and this can be purchased f.o.b. Regina for $124.00 and only occupies a space of 4' by 2' 6". I think the solution of the problem at St. Paul's School will be to purchase a 3 H.P. engine which can take care of the pumping arrangements and release the 6 K.W. plant to look after the lighting arrangements. As I stated in my letter of the 20th ult., I think the St. Paul's School Authorities consider that their school should be equipped similarly to the R.C. School on the same reserve and consequently may be over ready to condemn the equipment they now have.

I shall be glad to receive the Department's authority to take the suggested action and provide a 3 H.P. engine.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir:

Re: Storm windows for St. Paul School,
Blood Reserve

I beg to direct your attention to the urgent necessity of having storm windows supplied for all the windows of St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve. In a letter dated December 14th, the Rev. Canon Middleton Principal of this school writes as follows:

"During the past week we have been favored with an old time storm and blizzard, of unusual intensity from the north. The temperature in consequence was rather low, twenty-five to thirty degrees below zero. All the north side of the building was very cold, so cold as a matter of fact, that the class rooms were not habitable for the pupils during school hours. We had from three to four pounds of steam constantly at the boilers, yet despite this enormous pressure, neither dormitories nor class rooms were heated enough for use. You will recall that the storm windows which were originally meant for the building were withdrawn and after great difficulty during the last very cold winter, we were able to obtain storm windows for the west side of the building only. It is quite probable that with the aid of storm windows on the balance of the school, that some of the existing difficulty would be more or less overcome. Moreover, the boilers were kept going day and night and during the most severe weather we were burning more than two tons of coal daily."
"I am submitting the above for your consideration in the hope that something may be done in order to eliminate the excessive consumption of coal, and that the building may be made more comfortable by the installation of storm windows."

As the provision of the storm windows in question is, as I have stated above, an urgent necessity, I beg to request that steps be taken by your Department to have these provided at the earliest date possible. Should the expenditure which the provision of these windows would involve, be beyond the appropriation which you are making for this school for the current year, the school management will be prepared to have deferred the erection of the Utility Building until the next fiscal year in order to make the provision of the storm windows possible in the immediate future. It is hoped, however, that a sufficient appropriation has been made not only to provide all the items on the list forwarded to your Department through our General Secretary, but the storm windows as well.

I commend this matter to your prompt and sympathetic consideration, and remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

I beg to inform you that on the 18th December last I received a telegram from the Indian Agent on the Blood reserve, informing me that the heating worm in the large boiler at the St. Paul's School had burst causing bad foaming, and that it required immediate repairs. He stated that he had authorized Flett, a plumber at Cardston, to drain the boilers at once, as the weather was then mild, and effect repairs before cold weather set in. In a letter following this telegram the Agent advised that Flett, the plumber, had stated that the trouble was due to using well water in the system, and that the water containing an excessive amount of soda had rotted the worm, and in consequence it was giving out and mixing with the soft water in the boiler, thus causing foaming which would lead to further trouble if not remedied. It is stated that unless soft water is used entirely in the system it will not be long before a number of the pipes corrode and will eventually burst. It is recommended that a soft water reservoir be installed to store soft water for use in the boilers only.

I am today in receipt of further information regarding this matter, and it is suggested that a concrete cistern with a capacity of 200 barrels be installed in the school, which would enable the engineer in charge to use soft water entirely in the jacket heater for the laundry, and also for the power plant engine, as the soda water is doing damage to this plant. I would think that six or seven hundred dollars would meet this expenditure, but I doubt whether anything can be done until Spring, as the ground is frozen.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Chene:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant with reference to bad odours emanating from the sewage disposal plant of St. Paul's School.

The chief cause for complaint, I believe, is the result of an extra toilet and washbasin which we installed in the basement of the rear extension some time after the main contract was completed. This was asked for because the engineer and outside men had to use the bath-room on the ground floor, and as these men often came from work very dirty, it made it difficult to keep this bath-room clean. I partitioned off part of the basement store-room opposite the kitchen, and placed a toilet and wash-basin there, with connection to the main sewer outside. The vent from this new bath-room was carried up through the roof of the one-storey rear extension, and when the wind is from the west, odours that can scarcely be called fragrant blow into the windows of the main building, and more or less permeate the atmosphere.

The remedy for this is very simple. Instead of venting the two fixtures mentioned through the one-storey roof, the present vent should be carried along the basement ceiling until a stack is reached in the main building, and then the odours would be discharged from the high main roof, and be carried away. I asked the local plumber to give me an estimate of cost for doing this, but he has neglected to do so.

Dear Sir:

Owing to inclement weather, and consequent heavy roads, my call at the above-mentioned school had to be deferred from the 5th instant as intended until the 11th.

Mr. Pugh, the Indian Agent, accompanied me to the school, and we were joined by Mr. F.W. Flett, plumbing and heating contractor, of Cardston, and also by the Reverend Principal, Canon Middleton.

I shall now take up the matters referred to in my letter of the 1st of May in the order in which they were then enumerated.

1. Offensive Sewage Pool. As previously mentioned, this pool forms at the end of the sewer line in a shallow ravine where the fall is not sufficient to carry the effluvia away. At times offensive odours are carried by the wind to the school building and playgrounds; and persons passing on the public highway alongside the pool come within the smell zone. I am enclosing a rough sketch which will give you an idea of the lay of the ground, and the location of the pool.

To overcome this nuisance I would recommend the digging of a narrow V-shaped trench as indicated by the red dotted line in the sketch. We should then get more fall by shortening the line in comparison with the winding, sluggish watercourse which the water must now follow to get away. The proposed trench would be about 225 yards in length, and would average not more than 3' in depth, and the cost should not exceed $100.00. The offensive pool would thus be transferred to a more distant point where it would no longer constitute a nuisance.

2. Water Supply. The Department's Engineer, Mr. Chene, wrote me stating that a further analysis of the water is necessary before a decision can be reached concerning the type of water-rectifying plant that may be desirable. I have written to the Provincial Bacteriologist requesting that further samples of the water about to be sent him be given a complete analysis, especially with respect to the hardness of the water, and when this report is received I will forward it to you promptly.

3. Boiler Breathing. It has been pointed out that the breaching from the heating boilers is of insufficient weight, and is sagging noticeably. This should be replaced by one of No. 10

This breeching is unusually extensive, starting from the ends of boilers, then running singly the full length of the boilers and past the steel I column where they come together in one large breeching before entering the chimney. I enclose a quotation for supplying and installing new breeching in 10 gauge iron for $500.00, or in 12 gauge at $450.00 (Snyder & Co.).

In a covering letter Mr. Snyder states that the 12 gauge iron is used quite generally in industrial plants, and the saving over the cost of the 10 gauge might be used in putting insulation on the wood ceiling over the breeching. The laminated ceiling is about 15" above the breeching.

Roof Water. The accompanying sketch shows the position of the downspouts which are now discharging roof water along the foundation walls to the detriment of the building. The red line in the sketch shows a tile drain line to carry the water from the four downspouts indicated to the main sewer just beyond the septic tank. It is proposed to place a length of cast iron soil pipe under each downspout, to connect with the tile drain starting 3' below grade. I gave full particulars of the labour and material necessary for this work to Mr. Flett, the local plumber, and he is submitting a quotation to the Indian Agent, which he in turn will forward to you.

Regarding the finishing of the 2nd floor in the main building of the school, I understand Mr. Pugh is forwarding you full particulars of what has been requested, and is procuring prices for the labour and materials involved. I might say, however, that I gave careful attention to the proposals, and these will be carried out without detriment to the building in any way, and will add very materially to the accommodation at present existing. It is also desired that an additional toilet be installed in boys' basement, for which a suitable space is available. I asked Mr. Flett to give separate quotations for each item on which he has been asked to quote.

I will write you further regarding Item No. 2 as soon as I receive the more complete analysis of the water asked for. I shall be pleased to co-operate in the carrying out of whatever improvements the Department may see fit to authorize.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

GUARANTEE

Capacity
We guarantee that the Permutit Water Softening Plant herein offered, when connected up and operated in accordance with our instructions and under the conditions set forth in this proposal, will be capable of treating and softening its specified amount of water having a composition as stated in the analysis given herein, at the specified rate of flow.

Quality of Softened Water
We further guarantee that the water thus treated and softened will not contain any lime or magnesia as determined by the test that no more than five (5) drops of Boutron & Boudet soap solution will be required to form a permanent lather in forty (40) cubic centimeters of the softened water.

In addition, we guarantee that there will be no free alkali or acid added to the water as it passes through the Permutit Zeolite Softener.

Freedom from Scale, etc.
We guarantee that the softened water will not deposit any scale, sludge or mud in boilers, condensers, feed water heaters, or in the cooling jackets of water jacketed equipment.

Materials and Workmanship
We agree to make good at our expense, within a period of one (1) year after date of delivery, any defects due to faulty design, workmanship or material in such a manner as we may deem necessary to the satisfactory operation of the plant.

Conditions
The Guarantees hereinbefore stated are based upon the condition that you operate the plant in accordance with our instructions including the use of the stipulated amounts of salt for regeneration and water per minute for washing, cleansing and re-washing each softening unit when its guaranteed capacity has been realized. Also upon the provision that you furnish any housing required and keep the plant and connections from freezing.

A variation in the lime and magnesia contents of the water causes a proportionate increase or decrease in the quantity of soft water which will be delivered and this guarantee is also based upon the condition that the appearance and composition of the raw water shall not vary appreciably from the analysis given herein, and shall be clear, neutral and free from iron, color, turbidity, acidity, oil and free alkali, and of a temperature not exceeding 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

SIPHON

Continuous Water Softener

(PATENTED)

The Siphon Continuous Water Softener operates automatically to introduce reagents in direct ratio to the volume of water, without being dependent upon any moving mechanical device. The patented siphon reagent feeding device operates directly from the inflowing water, automatically regulating the volume of reagents to varying volumes of water—the principle being that of a main raw water siphon actuating an auxiliary reagent solution siphon so that the two flow in unison. The reagent feeding starts and stops with the starting and stopping of the flow of water. This apparatus is made to apply treatment with such reagents as lime, soda ash, aluminum sulphate, caustic soda, ferrous sulphate and others, the choice of reagents depending on the character of the impurities of the water supply.

The reagents are mixed in one or more solution tanks from which they are pumped to their respective solution regulators, in which constant level "B" is maintained; the surplus solution returning to its solution tank through an overflow pipe.

The raw water enters the receiving tank containing a siphon of special design. When the level of water in this tank rises to elevation "A", the siphon automatically "makes" or goes into operation, discharging the water into the mixing compartment. The instant that this main siphon begins to discharge, the displacement produces suction on the...
SIPHON CONTINUOUS WATER SOFTENER

solution siphon and raises the solution level from "B" to the elevation "C", putting the solution siphon in operation which discharges through the reagent siphon seal into the mixing compartment. The reagent solution flow is maintained during the period of discharge through the main siphon. The discharge of water through the main siphon exceeds the maximum flow into the receiving tank; therefore when the siphon goes into action the tank is quickly emptied. When the water level reaches "E" the inrush of air "breaks" or stops the action of the main siphon. This releases the suction of the solution siphon which automatically stops the flow in the reagent siphon, dropping the level of solution to elevation "B", but with solution retained in the seal at elevation "D". The harmonious action of these siphons depends only on the periodic rise of the water level to "A" and it is independent of the rate at which the siphon tank fills. The number of discharges through the main siphon has a corresponding number of discharges of reagent solution; consequently when the proper ratio between water and solution is established it is automatically maintained regardless of the number of siphon discharges per hour.

Mixing and Acceleration of Reactions

The raw water and reagents are discharged into the mixing compartment, passing downward, and then upward. The reversal of direction of flow in the mixing compartment results in a thorough mixture of raw water and reagent solutions. The discharging of this mixture over the surface of the water in the reaction compartment of the settling tank gives equal distribution and prevents direct currents. From this compartment the water passes downward to the settling compartment and rises through a wood fibre filter to the treated water offtake, over this filter. By these means the treated water is equally diffused throughout the entire settling tank thereby obtaining maximum reaction, retention and settling. The filtration secured in the wood fibre filter usually is sufficient for cooling water.
SIPHON CONTINUOUS WATER SOFTENER

For boiler feed, raw water ice freezing, domestic purposes, etc., it is usual to supplement the fibre filter with a filter provided with a specially graded crushed quartz or silica sand bed to perfectly clarify the water.

Gravity or open tank filters are generally best adapted for use in this system. Pressure or closed tank filters are furnished where conditions warrant their use. These filters are confined to steel construction, while gravity filters may be constructed of wood, steel or concrete.

The filter bed is placed on layers of gravel in which is embedded a manifold to insure uniform filtration and an even distribution of water when washing. The filters operate with the water passing downward through the bed; when washing, the flow is reversed and water passed through to give sufficient velocity to carry off the accumulated sediment on the top of the bed. The filters are built for washing either with water only, or with air and water combined. Less water is required for washing when air is used.

The reagent feeding device has no moving parts to stick, wear out, plug up or require watchfulness to insure its operation.

The reagent feeding device is the most accurate method ever designed for proportioning a measured volume of solution to a measured volume of water through all ranges of capacity.

The design of the Reaction-Settling Tank, with its special mixing compartment, baffles and auxiliary filter produces complete mixing of the reagent solutions with the raw water, proper diffusion, maximum retention and settling, and preliminary clarification of the treated water.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I have attached herewith accounts in triplicate for the lumber etc., duly authorised, for repairs to the property at the summer Camp for the pupils of St. Paul's School. May I say, that this property is situated in the heart of the Rocky Mountains, and for many years past, we have taken both boys and girls (different times) to attend the annual camp. Needless to say, they always return greatly improved in health and well being.

The material thus procured has been used on what is known as the GIRLS' COTTAGE, thereby completing the repairs which have been needed for some time past.

The accounts are duly certified correct. Was very pleased to have the opportunity of discussing various matters with you. Canon Middleton, Principal of St. Paul's Indian Residential School on the Blood reserve, saying that he would like to be supplied with "a few" Fire Extinguishers suitable for hanging in the outbuildings, also an attachment to the water main for outside emergencies. As his letter did not make it at all clear to me as to just what he did want I wrote to Indian Agent Pugh, asking him to go into the matter and find out what was really needed and he now informs me that the Principal asks for two dozen of the Pyrene type of extinguisher in the one-gallon capacity, to be hung in the outbuildings, and for use in the dormitories and playrooms and perhaps three in the attic. The attachment for the water main for outside emergencies is to consist of 1000 feet of hose, with a small building to house same. In my opinion this latter item is altogether unnecessary. We are not providing water and hose for the protection of outbuildings that are a long distance from the school and where there is no danger of loss of life. It might be all right to put three or four of the Pyrene Fire Extinguishers in these outbuildings, and one or two more in the school. My recommendation is that they be authorized to purchase twelve Pyrene Extinguishers, and I think you will agree with me that the attachment I have described is not necessary. This, however, is for the Department to decide.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:-

I beg to advise the Department that I am in receipt of a letter from the Indian Agent at Cardston, informing me that the grate and lining in the water jacket heater at the St. Paul's School have burned out and require replacing. It seems to me this is something that the school authorities should attend to. I cannot see that the Department should be called upon to be constantly making repairs and replacements of this kind. Nearly every mail brings a letter of this kind and if the Department is going to be responsible for every little item of repair and replacement, it will be necessary to appropriate a great deal more money for the purpose. It certainly seems to me that the school authorities should be informed that they will be expected to attend to these matters themselves without help from the Department.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham

Sir:-

I beg to advise that while visiting the St. Paul's Anglican School in connection with the completion of attic, I took note of the condition of the rain water gutters and noted that all the lead work has split, and as a consequence the water leaked through the walls. The position of these gutters is such that if a leak occurs, the water runs behind the brick end between the walls, with the result that all the inner walls are simply mildewed and badly discoloured. I called this to the Inspector's notice on his recent visit, and it has occurred to me that the only cure is to carry the roof beyond the walls and then put in galvanized eaves trough and connect with the down spout. I appreciate the fact that this will be costly perhaps, but on the other hand with the continual drip of the water between the walls, eventually the plastering on the inside is going to rot and start falling.

I find that work was done on this eaves troughing in 1925, with a two year guarantee which has expired December, 1925, and apparently last Winter with its varying conditions has again buckled the lead and split in many places. In view of this condition I should be glad to know whether I shall insert anything in the estimates to take care of this.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) J. E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Re- St. Paul's School, Blood Reserve.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant on the subject of leaky eave troughs at St. Paul's School.

The history of this trouble makes painful reading, and dates back to the time the building was erected in 1924. First, we found the original galvanized lining of the troughs would not stand the extreme variations of climate. I consulted many authorities, including architects and contractors experienced in western construction and climatic conditions, and was assured that if sheet lead were used in the place of gal. iron, the lead would withstand the contraction and expansion without breaking, and our troubles would be over. Acting on this assurance, and with the authorization from the Department, I awarded the contract to line all the gutters with lead to Mr. F.W. Flett, of Cardston, a very experienced sheet metal man and roofer, and took a two-years-guarantee from him. For a time all was well, but last winter brought unprecedented and sudden changes in temperature, with intense cold and deep snow--and the trouble is more acute than ever!

The position of these gutters is such that any water leaking through the cracks in the lining tends to seep through the masonry and disfigures the interior plastering, a condition very much in evidence at the present time. One way, and a permanent way, of overcoming the difficulty would be to splice the existing rafters, and carry look-outs from the ceiling joists, and thus extend the roof far enough beyond the wall line to form a framework for a metal gutter where leaks into the building would be impossible. The objections to this method are 1st, the high cost (probably about $2500.00); and 2nd, it would detract somewhat from the present pleasing roof architecture.

There is no escape from taking measures of some kind if we are to save this fine structure from serious deterioration. On the 19th instant, after receiving your letter on the subject, I went out to St. Paul's, taking Mr. Scanlan with me in the belief that "in the multitude of counsel there is wisdom". We made a close inspection of the gutters, and found that the cause of leakage is very apparent, and comes from the buckling and cracking of the sheet lead--the very thing I was assured by experts would not happen.

Mr. Scanlan told me of his experience in stopping leaks in

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6372, file 764-5, part 4)
the metal roof of the Calgary branch of The Canadian Bank of Commerce. He used a patented asbestos cement preparation which he applied with a trowel over the leaks, finishing with a second application of a thinner substance applied with a brush. He states that the cement bonded itself tightly to the metal, and to the best of his knowledge the repairs are still standing up, although the work was done several years ago.

In any event I should not care to start extensive roof work at St. Paul's so late in the season. Also, before recommending costly changes in construction I wish to try out patching the leaks with the patented roof cement used by Mr. Scanlan. It is probable that we can stop the leaks in this way, and perhaps thus postpone the heavy expense of roof alteration for another year or two, and perhaps longer. At any rate it is our best way of getting quick relief from further leakage, and for getting over the coming winter without further water damage.

I have anticipated the Department's consent in sending for a few gallons of the necessary material, and as soon as it comes I shall have it applied where needed, and in accordance with manufacturer's directions. I hope to have this done before the present fine weather breaks. The cost will be merely nominal, and if it give the relief I expect of it, it will be an invaluable aid to us at this time. I do not pretend that this patching will permanently overcome the trouble, but according to Mr. Scanlan's experience it should at any rate give temporary protection.

I shall keep the Department informed as to the result of this experiment.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

Sir:

I have just received a letter from Mr. J. E. Pugh, Indian Agent at Cardston, reporting that corrosion from the water used at the St. Paul's School, which has split the casting, necessitated the purchase of a new jacket heater, and, as the heater supplied all the hot water in the school, a new one was immediately purchased.

This corrosion, which is a result of the peculiar quality of the water used, will, in the opinion of Mr. Flett, the plumber at Cardston, ultimately result in the corrosion of the pipes throughout the building, and when that time arrives it will be a costly matter to remedy the condition by replacing the pipes. The only solution of the difficulty now appears to be to get different water. It is pointed out that rain water is out of the question, as the present tank is supplying the laundry and the boilers, and cannot be relied upon to furnish additional requirements. The Agent states that there is a spring about three-quarters of a mile from the school which flows continually, and he is having a sample of the water tested with a view to proposing laying pipes from the spring to the school.

When I receive a further report from the Agent, I will communicate with you again on the subject.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a short report on the Boarding Schools situated on the Blood Reserve, which report was made by Mr. Inspector Christianson.

With regard to the water situation, this is a serious matter and it seems difficult to find a remedy for the condition described. I have been discussing it with the Dept. of Public Works of the Provincial Government here, who have buildings at various points throughout the province, and they inform me that they experience the same difficulty at many of their large institutions, such as the Battleford and Weyburn Mental hospitals, and so far they have been taking out the pipes and renewing them, as there seems to be no way in which they can be freed of the substance that collects on them. I note the Inspector uses the word 'corrosion', but this is not correct, as it is not corrosion that takes place, but an incrustation on the pipes.

I am afraid that the roof on the St. Paul's school will have to be changed. Roofs such as this one are not used in this country as they are impracticable. As the Inspector says, $2000.00, or in fact more, has already been spent in trying to remedy this defect, and it is as bad now as it ever was I understand. With regard to the brick walls on both schools, it seems to me we will have to put some kind of a preparation on these bricks or else build another wall with an air space between, but before taking any steps

APR 3 1929

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that while on the Blood Reserve I inspected both schools.

ST. PAUL'S ANGLICAN SCHOOL.

I found everything in good order at this institution. The school was well kept and the furniture well arranged and looked after. The children were well dressed and appeared to be in the best of health. There are a few matters which I wish to bring to your attention regarding this school. The water that they are using at the present time seems to corrode the pipes and I am afraid if something is not done that the hot water pipes will in a very short time become so filled up with the hard substance that collects on them that nothing will pass through. The jacket heater has been renewed twice since this school opened. The water is being tested, and Mr. Pugh had sent some of it away with a view of getting a report as to whether anything could be put in it to prevent the pipes from corroding. I also wish to report on the roof of the school. As you know, this roof only comes out to the edge of the walls and there are no eaves at all. The first drain pipes were found to be unsatisfactory and about three years ago there was $2000.00 spent on gutters and down pipes, which were of lead. In looking over—

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6372, file 764-5, part 4)
then over I found that the gutters had all cracked, not at the joints, but between the joints, and as a consequence the rain leaks through and a lot of it goes down between the walls, and the plaster is greatly affected. No doubt the interior of the school will be ruined if this continues. The Agent reported on this matter to you in his letter dated August 21st last, and you evidently discussed it with the Deputy, as later on Mr. E. Gardner Smith had instructions, I believe, to have the matter remedied. Mr. Middleton informed me that Mr. E. Gardner Smith had tried a certain kind of composition on part of the school, but it was leaking just as badly there as any place else, so apparently it was not a success. In my opinion there have been enough experiments made on these gutters, and I think before any further expenditure is incurred something definite should be decided on that we know will be a success. It is probable that the only plan that will prove successful will be to extend the roof over the wall so as to make eaves.

Re Fire Escapes.

The top floor of the school has been finished and on the girls' side the rooms are being occupied. There are no fire escapes on this portion of the school, and in case of a fire the only way of escape would be by the main stairs down on to the second floor and from there to the fire escape.

ST. MARY'S SCHOOL.

I found everything in A1 shape at this institution. The furniture was well arranged and well cared for. The children here also looked well and

-everything-
everything seemed to be going along smoothly. This institution had a fair crop last Fall but as was the case in connection with the crops of other farmers in that part of the country, it was badly frozen.

GENERAL FOR BOTH SCHOOLS.

I was glad to note that there seemed to be the best of harmony existing between the schools and the agency. I think both Principals realize now that our Agent has been giving them a square deal and that he is not just a piece of putty that they can do what they like with. Smith, the boys' supervisor at the R.C.School, was discharged, and this seems to have had the effect of quieting everything down. Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that while on the Blood Reserve I visited both the Boarding Schools in that Agency.

St. Mary's School

I found everything at this institution in Al shape. The children were writing on their exams, as it was getting near the holiday season. The grounds around the school were in the very best condition, and they have a fine garden as well as a beautiful lot of shrubs and flowers. Their crop looked exceptionally well, as it had been put in in the early spring, and they were busy doing their summerfallowing and breaking new land. The interior of the school was clean and tidy, and the children seemed to be in the best of health. The construction of a hog pen and implement shed was under way. An expenditure for this was authorized by the Department.

St. Paul's School.

At this institution I also found everything in good shape. Nurse McGarry is back there as Matron. During her previous tenure of office I found her to be a very capable woman and I must say I am very pleased to see her back. The interior of the building from one end to

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6372, file 764-5, part 4)
Inspector Christianson's Report on Blood Schools.

the other was spotlessly clean, and the furnishings were well arranged. The children were writing on their exams and they all appeared to be in good health. The grounds around the school were in good shape, and a real effort is being made to beautify the place. Shrubs and trees have been planted, and grass sown, and good results have been obtained. I might mention that a new Church has just been completed within the school grounds which cost in the neighborhood of $15,000. This is a very fine building and has a full-size basement which is to be used as a concert room.

Regarding the gutters on the school, about which there has been a lot of correspondence, I notice by a recent letter from the Department that they seem to be under the impression that the rain beats through the brick walls. This seems to happen but it has nothing whatever to do with the gutters. The gutters are right on top of the wall, and the inside wall evidently is hollow tile and the outside brick, and the water runs down between the tile and the brick, as the rafters in the roof only come out as far as the inside of the brickwork, and as the gutters do not hold the water it, naturally, has no other place to run than down between the walls. This streaks the plaster all over, especially on the north and west sides. While I was there, and it had not rained for about ten days then, one could smell must all through the building as though the plaster were rotting on the inside, which no doubt is what is happening, and if something is not done soon it will seriously damage the building.

I went thoroughly into this matter with Mr. Weston, who is the only contractor in that part of the country. I got ladders and went up and looked over the gutters and I found that they were simply cracked all over. In a great many places they seem to crack right close to the joint. With the movement of the building and the change in the weather they seem to expand and then bulge up, buckle and crack, and at the present time they are absolutely useless. The only solution in my opinion and that of Mr. Weston to remedy this was to bring the roof out past the wall, and then put on ordinary eave-troughing. This will entail a tremendous expense as it will mean tearing up a certain amount of shingles all around the roof and extending the rafters by splicing, then reshingling and putting on eave-troughing. If there is any other solution that will prove of permanent benefit I have not heard of it, and I have consulted several different parties who I know understand matters of this kind. Mr. Weston will submit figures for your consideration in the course of a few days. What I wish to emphasize is that something must be done as soon as possible in order to prevent further damage to the building.

Sir:-

On tearing up the old gutters it was found that where the rafters came down to the plate and tile this was not filled with concrete as should be for various distances on the west side of the building. It was also found that the rafters, angle irons, and stay bolts were not embedded in concrete as they should have been, and this left open spaces in the top of the wall and a natural place for the water to get in and run on down between the brick and plaster. There will be a small additional charge for having this filled up with concrete, but this will not amount to much. I beg to refer to Department letter of 9th April last with reference to the request for a second jacket heater for the St. Paul School on the Blood Reserve and to the Department's suggestion of a soft water storage tank. I have ascertained that there is a concrete tank for storing soft water, of a capacity of 200 barrels and this is used for the high pressure boiler, the heating boilers, and the engine cooling tank. The jacket heater heats water for the baths, sinks, basins &c and is at present supplied from a gravity tower tank which holds approximately 20,000 gallons and requires to be filled by pumping three or four times a week. In other words, the requirements are from 60,000 to 80,000 gallons per week and it would not be feasible to build a concrete tank of such capacity even if the rainfall could be depended upon to keep a constant supply of soft water available.
