Dear Sir:

You will have heard from Canon Middleton, Principal of our St. Paul's School on the Blood Reserve, that on the morning of May 26th last, the cow stable was completely destroyed by fire. As Canon Middleton informed me in his telegram that he had notified your Department of this loss, I did not consider it necessary on my part to notify you as well.

With regard to the cause of the fire, when the Principal sent his telegram on May 26th, followed by a letter of the same date, the cause was unknown. His letter in this connection reads as follows:

"In confirmation of the 'Wire' sent this morning stating that the cow stable had been completely burnt down between the hours of 9 and eleven this morning.

Immediately after 'Chapel' about 9.20, a girl saw smoke issuing from the barn. She gave warning, and we all rushed out. The Farm Instructor (Mr. Lawton) and several boys were up working on the garden. They also rushed down, and we manned a bucket parade—but all attempts to save the burning building were hopeless. I called the Indian Agent, also the Chemical Brigade from Cardston.

We were successful in saving the adjoining building. Owing to the intense heat, the pump house was slightly scorched, but no damage was done. Regarding the cause of the fire, that I do not know. Mr. Lawton left the stables long before the fire was first seen. There was some hay in the loft, recently hauled from the stack. There is a possibility that this may have heated, and thus started a smouldering, beyond that I cannot say. All the stock was out of the barn with..."
the exception of two calves, and these were speedily removed. There was a loss with some of the Feed oats, other than that, there was no damage only to the cow stable itself, which was completely burned down to the ground, and the stanchions now stand all twisted.

I regret to have to send in this report, but at the present all I can say is, that the cause of the fire is unknown.

Additional. As a future assistance towards securing help for outside buildings in case of fire, I wrote the Indian Department late in the year 1927, urging that a Stand Pipe with 1000' of Hose be attached. If such were fixed, I mentioned that it would tend to reduce the chances of fire spreading on both the main building (School) and the out-buildings. To this I received a letter from Ottawa dated December 15, 1927, stating—

"The Department is not prepared at the present time to supply the attachment consisting of "1000' of hose for the water main for outside emergencies".

May I add, that had this 1000' of Hose been attached as I recommended, the damage would have been reduced to a minimum. As it is there is no possible chance of saving the outbuildings in case of fire."

I have asked the Principal to furnish me with a recommendation with regard to the construction of a new building after he had talked the matter over with the local Indian Agent. I have not yet received his recommendation, but will write to you again in due course in this connection. As the horse stable at this School was very unsatisfactory in many ways, I am of the opinion that the plans for rebuilding could very well arrange for this building to be fitted up as a work-shop or for some other purpose, and that the new stock barn might be modelled after the one at the Old Sun School and have accommodation for the milk cows at one end, and for the horses at the other. A building of that type would be in keeping with the main school building and the school premises in general, and I commend this suggestion to your favourable consideration.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.O.C.

Sir:-

I am today in receipt of a letter from the Indian Agent at the Blood reserve, in which he informs me that the top of the range at the St. Paul's Anglican Boarding school is broken, and to put it in repair would cost $34.70.

Re: Sewage Disposal, St. Paul's School, Cardston.

Sir:

Referring to the Department's letter of May 26th, File No. 103-1-5D, on the subject of the drainage system at the above-mentioned school, I beg to report that I visited this school on the 9th instant.

I was accompanied by Mr. R.B. Goodchild, C.E., of the Water and Irrigation Office, Calgary, through the courtesy of Mr. Tempest, Commissioner of Irrigation, who loaned us a Department car for the trip.

The Rev. Principal, Canon Middleton, stated that during recent weeks very offensive smells had at times been noticeable in the school, the cause of which he was at a loss to account for.

On opening the manholes of the septic tank the source of the trouble was immediately apparent. The outlets from the siphon chambers had become almost totally blocked by sludge and solids during the 3 years since the tank was last examined, with the result that there was a flood condition in the tank itself, and an interruption in the free passage of sewage from the school to the tank, though a total stoppage had not occurred.

As the conditions constituted an emergency, and in consultation with Mr. Fugh, the Indian Agent, I engaged a reliable local man and helper to empty the tank, and make one or two changes with a view to preventing a recurrence of the trouble. By the time we left the school on the 10th instant the outlets from the siphon chambers had been cleared of obstructions, and functioning freely, and the smells complained of had entirely disappeared from the building.

The septic tank at this school was designed by Mr. R.B. Owens, B.A., Provincial Sanitary Engineer for Alberta, Edmonton, and it was made exactly to his plan. It is an "Aerobic Bed" type in which the solids are held in...
suspension on a series of perforated shelves, the liquid being entirely drained off and discharged at each working of the siphons. The advantage claimed by Mr. Owens for this design of septic tank is the quicker and more thorough action of the aerobic bacteria in the breaking up and oxidation of the solids held in suspension on the perforated shelves as compared with the action of the deep tank; also it was claimed that the effluent from such a tank is less objectionable. In theory, Mr. Owens may be correct enough, but in actual practice it has been found much more troublesome. For instance, in opening up the tank at St. Paul's School it was discovered that the perforated platforms had collapsed. Though the wood itself seemed as sound as when first placed, the action of the acids in the sewage had destroyed the nails, thus allowing the woodwork to fall into ruins. I gave directions for the entire removal of the woodwork, and the raising of the inlets to the siphon chambers to a level one foot lower than the level of the sewer inlet from the school, and grids to be installed to prevent solids from passing into the siphon chambers.

It is probable that the cleaning out of the tank and the changes mentioned, will carry the school along for a considerable time, but the objection to the present arrangement is in the shallowness of the tank now converted into the ordinary type, which may not have sufficient depth for thorough bacterial activity.

At the final outlet of the sewage system, about 300' distant from the school, a pool forms which when the wind is in a certain quarter carries the smell to the school. This pool is also close to a provincial highway, and complaints have been made from the public who travel this road. To extend the sewer another 200' would take it to a point well beyond the said highway, and overcome the smell nuisance complained of. This could be done at an outlay not exceeding $100.00. The Rev. Principal is most desirous that this extension be made, but as this feature of the trouble is scarcely an emergency, I told him I could not order it done without direct authority from the Department. I shall be pleased to carry out whatever instructions the Department may give in this regard. The proposed 200' extension would be at almost right angles to the existing sewer line, and would carry the effluent out of the line of the prevailing wind.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS

On the 7th instant instructions were issued for an investigation into certain troubles at the above School in connection with the sewage disposal system. If possible, the causes of the trouble were to be ascertained and advice given as to remedial measures necessary.

Acting on instructions given him to do the above work the writer proceeded to the School, on the 8th instant.

CONDITION COMPLAINED OF

According to information secured from the Principal, the Matron, and Mr. Ralph Weston, a contractor from Cardston, who is thoroughly conversant with the sewage disposal system, offensive odours have been noticeable both in and around the School for some time.
Mr. Weston supplied information to the effect that at times the sewer vents in different parts of the roof gave off a disagreeable smell.

CONDITIONS AS FOUND

A disagreeable smell was noticeable inside the buildings on the evening of the 8th instant, and, as there was no wind at the time, it was evident that the odour did not come from the outlet west of the School but from the School sewers.

On the morning of the 9th the manhole covers on the septic tank were removed and the tank was found to be full of sewage, the water level standing some three feet above the overflow pipe. It may be added that inch boards and "two-by-fours" were also floating about inside the tank. The syphons were found to be choked and the overflow pipe was also blocked.

From information obtained through Mr. Gardner-Smith, Superintendent of Construction in Alberta for the Department of Indian Affairs, it was calculated that the sewage was backed up to a depth of over two feet in the sewers inside the School buildings.

DESIGN AND POSITION OF PRESENT WORKS

The accompanying plan will show the details of the septic tank and the location of the works at present in existence. The septic tank when completed was expected to act as follows:- the sewage was led into the tank from
the main sewer, was divided by the baffle shown and was
then expected to flow out over the upper board platform
and through it to the third platform, and so on to the
bottom of the tank.

It was expected that the solids would all
be caught and held in the holes in the various platforms,
so that only liquids would reach the syphons.

This expectation was not realized, and from
information secured by the writer, it would seem that
the system has never functioned as it should have done.
Solids and bits of wood or rubbish have at times blocked
the syphons and the tank has gradually filled and backed
the sewage up and into the sewer pipes inside the building.

It may be added that the action of the acids
in the sewage destroyed all the nails in the platforms,
as a result of which the platforms became a tangle of
floating boards and "two-by-fours".

In order to ensure a permanent and proper
functioning of the sewage disposal system several
important alterations would appear to be very advisable,
viz:-

1. Depth of septic tank to be increased by some four
feet.

2. Some important changes to be made in the design of
the tank.

3. Septic tank to be relocated on lower ground further
from the School and playground.
4. Sewer line from septic tank to be relocated on steeper grade northward, with outlet well away from school grounds and from road allowance.

TEMPORARY REMEDIAL MEASURES UNDERTAKEN

Since funds for such extensive alterations are not available certain alterations are being made which, it is hoped, will go a long way towards preventing a recurrence of the past troubles although it is by no means certain that the hope will be realized. It can be confidently expected, however, that an improvement will result. All the lumber in the septic tank is being removed, the wall between the septic tank and the syphon chambers is being carried to the roof and an opening into such syphon chamber, a foot square, covered by a metal screen is being left in this wall.

The openings into the syphon chambers are being placed about 18 inches above the floor of the tank. The pool created will therefore be 18 inches deep - in the writer's opinion this is too shallow for a permanent remedy, but might serve as a temporary advantage until funds are available to put in a complete and satisfactory system.

In addition a long rod rigidly attached to each syphon dome is to be placed and held in a vertical position in each manhole by means of guides so that in case of a blocking of the syphons the dome covers may be raised by a man on the ground above, without it being necessary for
him to go down into the chambers.

ALTERATIONS AT SEWER OUTLET

In order to abate the nuisance of bad odours at the sewer outlet it is intended by means of about two hundred feet of wood stove pipe to carry the outlet to a point north of the road allowance as shown on the plan.

While this will improve conditions it is realized that it is only a temporary relief measure and that the sewer line should be re-located northward, as shown on the general plan.

PERMANENT REMEDY SUGGESTIONS

To put the sewage system at St. Paul's School in thorough order and to guarantee against any future trouble it is thought after mature consideration that nothing less than the following measures will suffice.

At Septic Tank -

(1) Floor level lowered four feet. (2) two baffle walls built - from the ceiling downward - in the septic tank, (3) wall between septic tank and syphon chambers raised to level of one foot above the bottom of the baffle walls, (4) a screen grid of \(\frac{1}{2}\)" rods, closely spaced, placed between baffle wall and wall between septic tank and syphon chambers, said screen to be about one foot below crest of dividing wall.

The design suggested is one that would closely follow that which was put in at the School at Union Lake, in 1928.
It is also recommended that the sewer line from the septic tank be relocated to the northward instead of westward as at present. By so relocating this line, the outlet will be removed to a point where it will not give offence to the school population nor to the passers-by on the road allowance. Many complaints have been received in the past by reason of the proximity of the sewer outlet to this main road.

To lower the septic tank at its present location and to relocate the sewer line from it at this lower level would be very costly. It is considered that by far the better plan would be to construct a new septic tank some two hundred feet nearer the barn - away from the playground near which it now is situated.

The ground at the location suggested is about four feet lower than that where the tank now is, and from this new location to the point suggested as the new location of the sewer outlet, the ground falls some twenty feet. It is therefore plain that the fall both to and from the septic tank is ample, and that there will be a minimum of deep trenching.

It is thought that no useful purpose can be served by making an estimate of the cost of the proposed changes as it may be some years before the work is done, when prices may be very different.

The measures already taken may cure the trouble and so render the greater outlay unnecessary.

July 25, 1931.

Dear Sir:

On a recent visit to the Department of Indian Affairs I was very much disappointed to learn that it is proposed to alter the plans for the proposed Church of England Residential School on the Blood Reserve, Southern Alberta, in such a manner as to destroy the attractiveness of the general appearance of the buildings and, to some extent, impair their utility from the standpoint of administration.

In the earnest hope that the order for the carrying out of the proposed changes may be countermanded, I beg, respectfully, to ask your careful consideration of the following points:

1. The Church of an land in Canada, through its Missionary Society, provides for the purposes of Indian Residential School Education a much larger annual sum of money than any other non-Roman religious body in the Dominion.

2. The amount so provided for the year 1923, in excess of the total per capita grants, was the large sum of $65,035.47.

3. The Blood Reserve represents perhaps, the largest Church of single Indian responsibility in the Dominion.

4. The Church of England established at its own cost the first Residential School on the Reserve.

5. Missionary authorities of the Church have earnestly anticipated for many years the supersession of its own inadequate and unsightly building by those of an adequate and dignified institution provided by the Dominion Government, whose wards the Indians are, on a scale which should be worthy of the Government and acceptable to the Church.

6. The plans as drawn fully responded, in our opinion, to the requirements noted.

7. The contract was formally awarded for the erection of the building in accordance with the plans as drawn.

That the proposed changes in the plans will transform the proposed school from the appearance of a dignified institution, worthy of the Government as the builders and of the Church as the administrator, into the form of a common everyday building which, as far as the exterior appearances are concerned, might be mistaken for a "paper box factory" or any similar erection for industrial purposes.

9. That a number of buildings on the general scale and dignity of the plans as first drawn have been erected for other religious administrative bodies.

10. That to truncate and mutilate the plans, as drawn, in the directions proposed, will prove the severest disappointment to the great numbers of our supporters who are keenly interested in the Indian Residential Schools, who are making definite sacrifices in time and money for their support, and who, rightly or wrongly, will regard the carrying out of the proposed changes in the plans as, in effect, an act which is unfair to, and discriminatory against, the Church of England in Canada.

Sir:

I wish to advise that on a recent visit to the St. Paul's Anglican school, the condition of the hog pen was called to my attention. The flooring, which is of plank, has all rotted away, and is therefore in a bad condition, and impossible to keep clean. It would require, approximately, 1300 sq. ft. of planking at a cost of $45.00 per thousand, and the labor of laying, which would probably entail three days labor for two men at $1.00 per hour for a 10 hour day, a total cost of $157.00.

The Principal is desirous of moving this building to another site and requests that I place this before the Department. This would entail new cement foundations as well as the cost of moving, and re-planking floors; the total cost of this latter work would be, approximately, $350.00.

Sir:

With further reference to my letter No. 402-11 C.E., of the 23rd ultimo, I beg to state that the high pressure laundry boiler mentioned in the above letter has been examined and it is found to be badly pitted in the crown sheet and the walls and tubes. It appears that on this account that the boiler inspector last year cut down the pressure, and as reported by me, it has now started leaking badly, and I am advised that replacement would be the most satisfactory, in view of the fact that practically all the tubes are leaking and the walls and crown plates are pitted. The cost of a 6 h.p. Leonard upright boiler installed is $450.00, and I would, therefore, seek instructions in the matter. I have had no repairs made to the boiler pending the Department's decision as to replacement.

I may say that the water problem at this school is bad from a corrosion point of view, and it might be an economy to install a water softener in this plant when conditions improve.

Sir:

I beg to bring to your attention in connection with the St. Paul's Residential School on the Blood Reserve, that a steam register is required in the clothing room. This has been asked for on several occasions.

Without the register, the room in question is cold, and the clothing in winter is always damp with frost when taken out of this room. If the register were supplied, this would be overcome.

A plumber from Cardston would have to install this register. The cylinder in the well should also be lowered, as very often they are out of water for awhile until it rises. There is an abundance of water in the well but in order to take advantage of it a 20-foot length of 2" pipe is necessary to lower the cylinder. It would be necessary to have Mr. Flett from Cardston do this work, as the school has not the proper equipment to make the change.

I trust that both the register and the lowering of the cylinder will be authorized as both are required and the cost would not be very great.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have the honor to submit herewith vouchers nos. 11458, 11459, 11460, 11461, 11462, 11463, and 11464, in favour of R.W. Slett, plumber of Cardston and amounting to respectively $19.54, $21.85, $73.87, $23.90, $11.80, $17.20 and $2.60, and I wish to report as follows on these expenditures made at the St. Paul's Anglican school.

Voucher no. 11458 - $19.54. Under authority of Letter No. 103-115, dated October 25th, 1932, authorized charge of £60.00. This smoke stack metal extends from the kitchen flat roof to the elevation of the school building roof, and on account of its length, approximately 30', it is stayed by wire stretchers. When making the estimate on this it was thought that half of the metal could be used again, but it was rotted and unfit to use again, and the whole stack was therefore renewed, and re-erected from the base, and the cost therefore should be included. The work proceeded with the workmanship found it necessary to repair the whole structure. I may say that this is the third stack put up since the school was built, and I am of the opinion that a brick stack should be erected here, and I think, if stayed with iron rods, with an enlarged base, that it would be a lasting job. The stack is on the west side of the building, and being of such height, that when the metal deteriorates and high winds strike it, collapse usually follows.

Voucher no. 11459 - $21.85. This voucher covers repairs to pump in the barn, last fall when the pump went out of order, and repairs became a necessity, as this is the only water for stock available without laying lines from the school proper system.

Voucher no. 11460 - $73.87. This work was executed in December, as the well became practically dry. Authority was given later to lower the pipes and add a 20' length with rods and couplings. On pulling the pipe it was found that the well would take a further 20 feet of pipe and couplings and would then be in 30 feet of water, and I authorized Mr. Slett to put on the additional pipe and rods etc.

Voucher no. 11461 - $23.90. This voucher covers the cleaning out of closets and sewer line on the girls' side of the school. These were clogged and the services of the plumber obtained to put them in order again. The latter portion of the voucher is for repairs to the kitchen sink.

Sir,

I have to state in further to my wire of the 10th instant, which referred to damage to heating system at the St. Paul's Anglican School, that in company with plumber, I went to the school yesterday afternoon, after a call from the Principal, and found that a pair of radiators in the dormitory on the S.W. corner of the building had frozen, splitting practically all the cores and the piping, and in the toilet a radiator also split and ruined, and the newly installed radiator in the clothes room, under the chapel. This was on the third floor. On the fourth floor on the S.W. corner, one toilet and the pipe connections had been frozen, and in the dormitory, in the middle of the fourth floor on the west wall, a toilet that had also frozen solid.

I made inquiry in regard to the firing of the boilers in the night of the 9th and 10th February, which without doubt was one of the worst storms experienced in the south part for long time, a wind of 35 miles an hour, with snow shifting and the temperature around 10 below zero, and I feel satisfied that there was no fault in the firing, both boilers going and the fireman up all night till 4 A.M., stoking, when he was relieved.

The position of the radiators is under windows, and we are of the opinion that the cold air striking the radiators caused condensation and the freezing.

I believe that a saving can be effected on the price quoted of about $100.00, as the oil tanks after being emptied, are not beyond repair, and it will not be necessary to renew these, but the radiators will have to be new.

I am enclosing a sketch showing the position of the radiators in the dormitory, and in replacing I think it would be wise to utilize the blank wall space and get away from the windows and the consequent drafts in weather of the type we are experienced in the same week.

I may say that I deemed it advisable to wire the department in this regard, and have not proceeded with the work of repair pending the department's authority.

Your obedient servant,

If the traps on the radiators are working properly there should be free circulation of the water condensation back to the boiler, and water should not lie in the radiators. It would be well for the Engineer at the School to check these traps at different periods to see that they are functioning properly.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your 402-11A of the 29th ultimo, with reference to the well at the St. Paul's Indian Residential School.

For your information, I may say that no funds were specifically provided in this year's Appropriation for work at the St. Paul's School, and, under these circumstances, the Department is unable to authorize any expenditure in connection with the well.

I would suggest that the school authorities have this work done at their own expense; and, when it is completed, you may submit the receipted account to the Department. The matter of making a grant to the school towards the cost will then receive further consideration.

Inspector's Office,
Calgary, Alta.
While we were working on this well, the Principal of the St. Paul's Anglican School advised me that their pump had broken on September first—and the children in school. I went to the school to find that they were also out of water and found that the rods had been broken off in the bottom of the well and the leather in the valves reversed and worn. I, therefore, deemed it advisable to pull this pump, and accordingly got the driller to set there at a cost of $75 to draw the pump and clean this well out, which was done. We found about six feet of a shale of fine grade in this well, but the brass barrel in good shape. The rods were repaired by Weston Bros. of Cardston. That well is now working in good shape. I did find, however, that in this well the pump sits fairly well up, is a 4" pipe pump, and the well casing is as shown in the log, reduced, and therefore the pump cannot be lowered. I would suggest that when next this well is worked on that a 3" pump pipe be used and then lowered into the well casing.

As with the Blood School, I put in a lot of time at the Anglican School, and the cost of this work will be $75 for well rig and work, and a charge for repairs to rod and help in getting the rods out, etc., to get a supply of water, pending the cleaning of the well.

Both schools rendered assistance in the work, particularly the Blood R.C. School, as the work is heavy, and the expense was kept down in this respect, using only two on the well rig, and I may say that, by careful planning, the two jobs have been done under the cost I estimated, and as a consequence of the break down at St. Paul's School, I did that job without wiring the Department for authority, as it appeared an absolute necessity to satisfy myself and the schools that an efficient water supply be maintained from all points of view. I trust the Department will concur in my actions in the matter.

The total cost of both jobs will not exceed $350.00, and the Department may be assured that the work was done economically, and that the water supply is sufficient at both schools.
Blood Indian Agency,
Cardston, Alta., October 19th, 1933.

Sir:-

I beg to report that I have today authorized the local plumber, of Cardston, to replace the heater (hot water) at the St. Paul's Anglican School.

I was advised that the one in use had split with sediment, and that there was no hot water. I may say in this connection that about two years ago authority was given to purchase an extra heater, and it was then proposed to alternate these heaters and this has been done about every six months. This time it lacked a month or more to the change, and apparently the sediment has been greater and corroding set in faster with the result that the heater split.

Kindly advise if an extra heater should be purchased at a cost of $125.00 to $130.00.

We have found at this school, due to the corroding quality of the water, that a hot water jacket heater will not last a year, hence the reason of having an extra heater to alternate.

I trust the Department will concur in my authorizing the replacing of the extra heater under the circumstances. The cost will be for labour and minor fittings only.

Your obedient servant,

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection made last week of the St. Paul's Indian Residential School in the Blood Agency:

BUILDINGS:

The school and out-buildings are in a first class state of repair. Considerable painting and calsoining has been done lately on the inside of the building. The furniture was in excellent shape; all being well arranged and given proper care.

A new floor is required in one of the dormitories occupied by girls. The present flooring is edge-grained fir, and is badly worn; in fact in several places where the beds are moved around, it is worn down to the rough flooring. This should be looked after whenever money is available.

The machinery in the school is all in fair shape but the power plant is beginning to show wear and will soon require a general overhauling. The present engineer.....

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6372, file 764-5, part 5)
Buildings. (Continued),—

engineer seems to handle the plant and other machinery very satisfactorily, but naturally machinery that has been running for 10 years will show considerable depreciation. The present plant is a Lister Bruston and in my opinion the sooner it is given a general overhauling, the better. This company has been taken over by the Delco Light Company but they retain several men from the former company and in conversation with the Manager here recently, he informed me that some of his experts would be in the southern part of the province sometime during the summer.

What the plant requires, besides the general overhauling, is two new cylinders and pistons and rings, and new bearings; also connecting rods.

The grounds around the school are well kept and considerable improvement is noticed each year. When the foliage is all out and the grass is green it is quite a beauty spot.

The out-buildings are all in a good state of repair and have been well kept. The water tower, however, is giving considerable trouble and needs repairing, as it is leaking badly. It also needs painting. The well went dry sometime ago and had to be cleaned out, and I was informed by the Principal that at the present time they had to pump practically 24 hours a day to keep the school properly supplied.
Buildings, (Continued),-

with water. If it goes dry as it quite possibly might do, this would be a calamity. The present well is 140 feet deep and at the time the school was built there was ample water: I was there several times while it was being built and had the quantity of water in the well tested. I would recommend that we have Mr. Fetterly of the Dominion Water Power Branch look into this matter sometime during the summer.

FARMING:-

The farming operations of this institution were more or less of a failure last year. They threshed no grain whatever on account of drought, but raised sufficient potatoes and other garden truck to carry them through the winter. They have about 70 head of cattle of which 35 are cows. At the time of my visit they were milking 17 cows. They also have 18 horses and some pigs, but no chickens. They intend to crop 200 acres of wheat and about 60 acres of oats this year and are putting in a larger garden. They have not sufficient cattle to meet the beef requirements of the school so considerable beef is purchased from the butcher shop in town.

HEALTH:-

The children all looked well and were well clad and I am quite sure are being properly cared for. At the time of my visit there were 56 boys and 85 girls, a total of 141 present.
Health, &c., (Continued),—

I also checked over the clothing for both boys and girls and considered that they were well supplied with good warm clothing. Both boys and girls are getting a fair training at this institution, as the boys do all the outside work on the farm, in the garden, &c., and the girls receive very good training in household science which should fit them for the home life on the reserve after they leave school. Miss McGarry, the Matron, is a very capable woman and her influence at this institution has certainly been of great benefit to the children.

GENERAL:—

The cook stove at the school is in poor shape, badly burnt out, and has more or less passed its usefulness, and the Principal is asking that the Department supply him with another stove as soon as this can be arranged. I might say that this is not a case of asking for a stove because the other school received one a short time ago; I looked over the stove myself and realize that it is in bad shape. What would be required would be the same kind as was supplied to St. Mary's School recently.

As a whole things are quite satisfactory at this institution and I was quite pleased with the progress being made.
STAFF:

The staff at the school, as far as I could ascertain, are all rendering good service.

Trusting this report will be of interest to you,

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir:

With reference to my letter of the 5th instant in connection with the water situation at the St. Paul's Anglican School on the Blood Reserve and my report on the school, as there is a scarcity of water in the well there, I asked that Mr. Fetterly of the Dominion Water Power Branch be sent down to the school to find out where the trouble is.

I am now in receipt of a letter from the Indian Agent who was with me at the time I inspected the school, and he states the situation is now getting serious. He is not sure whether it is on account of a scarcity of water in the well or whether part of the cylinder walls are worn and as a consequence the water goes by the leathers and the wall of the cylinder and therefore the lift to the water-tower is weak.

I would now suggest that as soon as the Department receives this letter, arrangements be made by wire to have Mr. Fetterly visit the institution to check up on the trouble.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Re. St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School on the Blood Reserve.

A preliminary inspection of the water supply of the above School was made on the 23rd inst. I also interviewed Canon Middleton, The Pump Engineer, Mr. Pugh, the Indian Agent and Mr. Flett of Cardston, plumber.

A copy of the log of the well which shows the depth, water level, length and size of the different casings used, also size of pump is attached.

It will be noted that the well was cleaned out in September, 1933, when the piston was removed May 1st, the old leathers were found to be badly worn and new leathers were put on. It has been known for some time that the cylinder is badly worn and when the new leathers were put on, they were loose in the cylinder. A pumping test was carried out which showed the efficiency of the pump to be only 50%.

As the water goes up and down with the piston, the Engineer is of the opinion that the check valve under the cylinder is loose and not holding the water. This was not replaced on May 1st when piston was removed. The trouble started about Christmas 1933. The St. Mary's Indian School had similar trouble last year. The pump was taken out, and a new cylinder put in. No further trouble has been experienced. The well there is down over 200 ft.

At the present time there is about 2' of water in the tank and even pumping 18 hrs. per day it is impossible to build up any reserve. The water supply has been cut to the minimum and as a consequence the lawns, shrubs, garden, etc., have suffered. A fire would be disastrous.

RECOMMENDATION.

That a brass ball type working barrel No. 2460, 3½ x 39" be ordered at once. When it arrives the pump should be taken out and thoroughly overhauled. Also 20 ft. of 3" cast pumping pipe threaded 8 to the inch be ordered as well. If the system then fails it will be due to lack of water and this can only be overcome by sinking a new well. The old well cannot be

O.M. Hoover, M.E.,
Engineer-In-Charge,
Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
Calgary.
deepened.

The general opinion is that the present well is too shallow. From the log you can see that rock formation was encountered at 86 ft. when a smaller casing was used for a further 56 ft.

Your obedient servant,

(signed) W.T. McFarlane.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith Voucher No. 647, in favour of the Bruce Robinson Electric, Ltd., of Calgary, covering the overhaul of the Lister Lighting plant and the Lister pumping engine at the St. Paul's Residential School.

The repairing of these plants has exceeded the estimated amount, but when these engines were taken down, several unforeseen breakages were in evidence. On the 6 h.p. engine, the water hopper was split, it was replaced, one bearing and valve guide and valves badly worn and replaced. On the 12 h.p. lighting engine, valves and guides were replaced, and the crank shaft had to be trued, and a fly wheel fitted in Lethbridge, vide my letter re voucher No. 627 for the Lethbridge Iron Works.

The plants have been put in first class shape, but one is prompted to state that with plants of this type, now in use for ten years, that a yearly overhaul is necessary. Constant running is required in winter months, and during the course of twelve months, considerable wear is bound to appear.

The account submitted is fair in all its charges, under the circumstances, and I would recommend the payment thereof.

Sir:

I beg to state that recently I was called to the St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School in connection with their plant (lighting and pumping), the report being that the generator (Lister plant) was sparking excessively. I proceeded to the school, and made examination of the whole plant, as far as I am able. I found that two or three segments of the commutator on the generator were shorting, and as it looked more or less serious, I moved our generator from the Agency to the school in case of theirs burning, and called in an electrician and had some work done on them, and it will carry them for a time. Eventually however, it will have to be replaced. I also checked over the batteries, and had the electrician check them over, and we find that these will have to be replaced shortly with new ones. Both engines are in need of overhaul, the lighting engine being out week, with loss of compression etc. The water cooling tank was almost done, and the galvanized iron all eaten out at the top. This I had replaced at once as there was a danger of it bursting. The cost of this will be about $30.00.

Having looked over the whole plant carefully and ascertained known costs of repairs to engines, new batteries, repairs to generator, I discussed the matter with the Principal as to installing Calgary Power Co., and the Church authorities reaction should the Department consider same from an economical point of view. The cost of above repairs etc. would be approximately, engine $200.00; generator repairs around $60.00, or perhaps more if complete rewinding had to be done; new batteries at about $600.00, a foreseen total of $960.00. The batteries apparently last about four to five years, and the engines were overhauled two years ago. Hence I am placing the matter before the Department for their consideration of installing Calgary Power services at this school, the estimate was gotten on the necessary line etc. when the Agency and R.C.School were placed on that Company's line. Sir:

I beg to herewith forward a voucher in favour of Wilkinson Electric Company, Limited, of Calgary, in connection with the change made at St. Paul's School at Cardston in the electric energy, from our own plant there to service from the Calgary Power Company's lines.

When this matter came up I endeavoured to get the best information I could as to the cost of the change-over, and the Operating Supt. of the Calgary Power Company estimated the cost at between $300 and $400, so I sent in an estimate of about $500. I now find that it is costing us a little over $600.00, and this includes the two motors and many other things too numerous to mention. When this came up I was under the impression that the electrician in Cardston would be able to do the work, but Mr. Pugh advised me that the man down there would not take it on as he did not consider he had sufficient knowledge of the work. It was necessary to send workmen down from Calgary, and they took the material down with them on a truck, and when they got there they got in touch with Mr. Pugh and proceeded with the work. As you know, Mr. Pugh is quite a mechanic and very practical, and nothing has been supplied but what was absolutely necessary. He has reported to me that the work was done in a very satisfactory manner, and that the system is in A.1 shape.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your 402-11 R.C. of the 27th ultimo, the Department regrets that the water towers at the St. Paul's C.E. and the Blood R.C. Indian Residential Schools were not painted during the last fiscal year. Funds were available for that purpose. However, it is noted from your letter that the material for both schools is now on hand and you may arrange for the necessary work. It is further noted that the cost of the labour will be $111.00 at each school.

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE
PB CALGARY, ALTA., May 18th, 1936.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of St. Paul's C. E. Indian Residential School on the Blood Reserve:

The buildings are in a fair state of repair and apparently well taken care of in every way. The furnishings are well arranged and in good order.

The Department will recall that the machinery at this institution went out of order during the winter and arrangements were made with the Calgary Power Company to connect it up with their power line. The old engines are no longer in use, and pumping, etc., is now done by electricity. The boilers are in good working order as they were fixed up during the winter.

It was brought to my attention that the cement between the bricks was beginning to crumble away and that it would be necessary to point the brick-work. This was provided for in the estimates. The roof of the main building also requires painting whenever funds are available, and provision was made for this expenditure in the estimates. The outbuildings also require painting, but this was not provided for. We furnished the school with some paint.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6372, file 764-5, part 6)
last year for interior decorating, and the work was done by the Staff. Canon Middleton informed me that if an additional amount was supplied this year the Staff would again do the painting inside.

The grounds around the school are in good shape and considerable work has been done by Canon Middleton and his staff in beautifying them.

The health of the children has been very good this last winter and they all looked fairly well. The only thing that was brought to my attention was that the epidemic of Measles there sometime ago had left the children with weak eyes, which very often happens with that disease. Doctor Wall will be there shortly, I believe, and he will go into this matter.

I found that the children were furnished with ample clothing and in checking up on the meals I found they were very well fed.

Farming:— Farming was more or less of a failure last year owing to the drought, but the School is seeding approximately 200 acres this spring, and the work was well under way when I was there. They also have a good garden, and as a rule raise sufficient potatoes and garden truck for their own use. They have quite a number of cattle and horses, and have a total of 40 cows, 21 of which were being milked at the time of my visit, which supplies them with milk and cream, and they also make butter.

Training of Children:—

The Provincial School Inspector inspected this school a short time ago and he remarked that
it would be of great benefit to engage another teacher. I discussed this with Canon Middleton and he informed me that several of the children from the junior room, which was overcrowded, would be advanced to the senior room this spring, which will take care of the situation and that the matter would adjust itself, as he stated the commission would not sanction the appointment of another teacher.

As far as the academic work in this school is concerned, I would say this is very satisfactory and that the children are getting a good education in the classroom. I am, however, of the opinion that the farm work might be better done and the boys given a better training in this respect. I am not in a position to say very much about this as the land was just being plowed and harrowed, but their returns from farming operations have not been as good as they should have been. I shall go into this matter the next time I visit the reserve, which will be during the summer, and see how the work is performed. The girls receive a very good training, and as a whole I would say the school is doing very good work.

The Staff consists of the Principal and 6 other male members, and 5 lady members — a total of 15. The Department know that Canon Middleton's daughter is on the teaching staff, and his son is acting as Farming Instructor. Probably this will work out well, but personally I am never enthusiastic over such a family arrangement.

The Staff all seem to be doing satisfactory work and they are very busy.
In conclusion I wish to point out that I would recommend that $125.00 be authorized for interior decorating, and if the painting of the roof of the main building and the pointing can be allowed, this work is necessary as soon as funds can be provided. Authority for whatever work is to be allowed might be sent either to Mr. Pugh or myself.

Your obedient servant,

The Agent states that the latter has since withdrawn his quotation and does not wish to do the work.

I would recommend, for your approval, that Mr. Pilling be given the labour in painting the roof of the main building, for the sum quoted by him, viz.: $150.00.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

I have the honor to submit herewith my report for the month of August.

SCHOOLS

Both schools were visited during the month, largely for repair jobs to be looked into. No children being in school this month. At the St Paul's Anglican School, paint was provided for the school and the labor of painting being done by the staff. Brick work pointing was done on all the windows, doors and coping stones on the roof. Roof painting was not carried out, the matter being placed before the Department regarding the labor entailed in the work. At the Blood R.C. school, their repairs were looked over and the matter referred to the department, and the work necessary and authorized is now being proceeded with. Crops at both schools was very poor, averaging about 4 bushels to the acre. The potatoe crops were also useless and they will be faced with purchases in both flour and potatoes.

J. E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to confirm my night lettergram of the 20th instant, and is herewith quoted:

"Main pump Jack St. Paul's Indian School broken down can only make temporary repair. Necessary replace at cost of three hundred fifty dollars. Replacement present account low water supply. Please advise."

In this connection I wish to state that I was called by the Principal a week ago by phone, and he advised me at that time that the pump jack was making a grating noise. This I presumed to be the gears, and said so, and advised that the Engineer keep his eye on the jack, and I would visit the school. Friday last I called at the school in response to a phone message, stating that the jack had broken down. On enquiry it was found that a key in the big gear on the left side had come out, and consequently, the pinion teeth had been broken out, three in number, the pitman arm broken, and the pins in the cross head snapped off and other minor breakages.

Repairs were made to the main frame some time ago, which was broken, due to loose gears and consequent wearing of keys, and the school paid for the welding job. I found that they had only around 1500 gals. of water in the tank, and it was therefore necessary to make temporary repairs, but this will not stand up very long, and I, therefore, advised the Department of that condition, seeking replacement with a new jack.

This jack has been in use for thirteen years, but due to breakages, with subsequent repairs, it is now almost unfit for use. This recommendation would not be made unless it was considered necessary.

Department of Mines & Resources,

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith my report for the month of May.

SCHOOLS:
Both schools were visited during the month and class rooms visited. There were several children admitted to hospital from both schools during the month under doctors care.

Class rooms were bright and tidy, and the children appeared to be in good spirits. At the St Paul's Anglican School, Junior room, a shortage of desks was noted and a request has been sent in for six additional desks in that class room.

An unfortunate accident happened on Coronation Day when the pupils of the St Paul's School were en-route to Cardston, for the ceremonies, at that point. This matter was reported fully to the Dept. following the accident. I am glad to say that all the children hurt in the accident are progressing very well. One boy, Arthur White Man is still in hospital, but is getting along nicely. This boy was internally injured.

Sir:

REPORT FOR DECEMBER 1937.

At the St Paul's Anglican School, the Principal called my attention to the following repairs required; Kitchen Range, fire box Linings burnt out, Baking Oven, Burnt Out linings and estimates as to cost are being procured and will be submitted. Several radiators also leaking, and I am having an estimate made as to cost of repairs for these.

At this school, Xmas. festivities were held for all pupils and parents. Two truants were taken care of during the month, from this school and were returned by the parents the day following their truancy.

J.K. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Blood Indian Agency,
Cardston, Alta., January 13th, 1938.

Sir:

I wish to report further to my night letter of the 11th, regarding the repair and replacement of heating radiators in the water tower at the St. Paul's Anglican School, that I find that the breakage in this was discovered on the morning of the 11th, and I find that the Engineer had resigned and left the school that morning and I, therefore, had no chance to question him regarding this breakage.

On enquiry however from the Principal, I find that about two weeks ago, during a very cold spell of 20° below zero, that the Engineer found it necessary to refill the boilers, which would indicate that the radiators had been frozen during this cold spell, and with the mild weather since prevailing, there has been no heat used in the tower till the 10th - 11th, when a bad storm struck and it turned cold, and it was then that one of the employees went up into the tower to find the radiators all cracked and leaking. I may say that every fall I telephone both schools to see that the steam is put up into the towers before cold weather sets in, to prevent an occurrence of this nature, and in my opinion steam has been turned on too late, in other words, when there was too much frost, with consequent cracking.

As instructed, I have requested the local Plumber, Mr. F.W.Flett, who is on the "Approved list" to make the necessary repairs at a cost of $65.00 for radiator repairs. We may, however, find that the supply line is frozen, and if such is the case, the information will be sent forward at once. We cannot ascertain this latter until the radiator section is repaired.

Your obedient servant,

C. Pant. Schmidt, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
507 Public Building,
Calgary, Alta.

Sir:

I wish to state that a matter of equipment repairs for the St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School of this Agency has come to my attention, and the detailed items and cost are herewith enumerated.

1/ Kitchen range. The firebox lining burned out badly and will require a new set of linings as per requisition. Cost given in estimate by Cardston Implement Co., Cardston, (Approved list) $27.50.

2/ Bake oven. This also requires new linings and tinsmith repairs, and the cost of repairs in this case is given by Mr. F.W. Flett, Tinsmith and Plumber of Cardston (Approved list) at $30.00 to cover material and labour. Mr. Flett's remarks in this case are that this will only be a temporary job, as he is of the opinion that it is too light for the amount of baking done.

3/ Radiators. Three (3) of these are broken and have been since last Winter it appears, and are situated in the following places in the building:- Dairy, stock room and boys' intermediate dormitory.

They are beyond repair, and will require re-placement, and the estimated cost of new radiators and installation is quoted by Mr. Flett at $130.00. Fortunately we have not had many severe cold spells and they have been shut off. However, in severe weather they will be a necessity.

I have, I may say, just received an account from Mr. F.W. Flett for several items of work and material supplied to this school, described as follows: 1 1/8" sink trap 1 - 3/3" N.P. self closing stop cock, both at a cost of $7.50, and an account is being submitted for these items. I took the matter of these recurring items up with the Principal, with a view to avoidance, and I am informed that the school authorities themselves have taken care of an account for plumbing material etc. to the value of, approximately, $80.00.

Requisitions are attached herewith.

C. Pant. Schmidt, Esq.,

Calgary, Alta.

St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School.

Notes attached to February report.

Fire Circular of February 10th, 1938, No. 150-65, dealt with on inspection for this month's report.

Found that school is equipped with ten Pyrene small extinguishers, all empty, will require refills. It is thought that the brass cases are in good condition, though on examination found to be stiff in action. These have been in the building for 12 years.

Checked over the fire hose, eight sets, and I have asked that these be taken down and water put through them. From my observation, I am of the opinion that all this hose will require replacing. Further report on this when tests made.

In the matter of fire escape in this building, the top floor, which is occupied by senior boys and girls, there is no fire escape. This stops on the third floor. In case of fire, these children would have to go down the main staircase to the next floor and then on to escape. In my opinion this is dangerous.

Escapes should be provided from this top floor to roof of kitchen on south side and on to laundry on the north end.

I also note that the drop off at this school is similar to that at the Blood R.C. School.

If the Department desire to go further into this matter, sketch and plan of this building can be made?

The belting in laundry and powerhouse was called to my attention. This was found to be in bad shape, and I have ordered the belting at a cost of $15.30 from the Cardston Motors. (Approved list).
Blood Indian Agency,
Cardston, Alta., Feb. 28th, 1938.

REPORT FOR MONTH OF FEBRUARY 1938.

On checking over various matters called to my attention by the principal of the St Paul's school, only one was dealt with at once that of Belts for the laundry plant, and I authorized the purchase of the following belting; 16 feet of 1½", 16' of 2" and 24 feet of 4", all the belts were in a dangerous condition, being badly worn, the cost will be noted on the St Paul's school returns. This purchase was deemed advisable without waiting for authority as there is a danger where the staff and girls in the laundry are working, and I trust the department will concur in my action.

J. Pugh.
Indian Agent.

Sir:-

I beg to submit herewith Voucher No. 520, amounting to $17.30, in favour of Cardston Motors, Ltd., Cardston, Alta.

This voucher covers repairs to the pumping and line shaft 5 h.p. motor at the St. Paul's School, and in reference I would state that this motor seized in the bearings, and had to be sent to Lethbridge for new bearings. It was installed after repairs and again seized and had to be returned for further repairs. This entailed express to Lethbridge and return twice, and a delivery charge for repair man to the school for 13 miles. Receipts are attached for express to Lethbridge and return of motor for two trips.

I have assumed this account, as I was fully conversant with the matter at the time, and was very disappointed when the motor seized a second time, as I had issued careful instructions to the school on running the motor after new bearings were put in.

I trust the Department will concur in the expenditure.

Sir:
I beg to submit herewith my report for the month of June 1938.

SCHOOLS

Both schools were visited during the month, but classrooms were not visited. Except for the odd truant at the Anglican school, attendance was full at both schools. Examinations occupied the last two weeks of the term. St Paul's school had two or three pupils taking their exams, at the Cardston High school in the Higher grades.

Attendance was made at both schools on the last two Sundays of the month, at the prize giving. Both schools well attended by the parents for the occasions.

Repair work had to be carried out at the Anglican School on the Pump, taking out the rods and leathers, the latter we had to change and I note that the brass valve is badly worn, and will before long have to be renewed.

Both schools dismissed their pupils on the 26th June for the summer holidays, except for a number of girls over the age of 14 years, whom they have retained. I suggested to the principals, that in view of new regulations regarding holidays, I thought it advisable to let all children go, and place the responsibility on the parents of the older girls.

All boilers at both schools have been inspected by the Prov. Gov. Boiler Inspector.

J. E. Pugh

Sir:

BUILDING:

The school building is kept clean and in good repair. The outer buildings are properly cared for.

I noticed on opening a tap at one of the wash-basins that the air-pressure was exceptionally strong. I am afraid this is caused by the hard water, a certain amount of corrosion forming inside the pipes, which reduces the water flow and causes the air pressure to be too strong. I would suggest having this checked over; also the steam boilers, to ascertain whether there is not some damage being caused through the system generally, by the water now in use.

When you obtain this report you should forward it for our consideration. However, as our funds for the current fiscal year are practically all assigned it is doubtful if we can provide any amount for changing the water system in the event of such action being recommended.

Sir:

I beg to state, further to my letter No. 402-ll C.E., of the 8th instant, that further investigation into this matter of water tank damage at St. Paul's Anglican School reveals two splits in the riser pipe of this tank, and it became necessary to strip down the boxed casing of the water riser and steam pipe casing up to the tower, and this revealed the condition referred to above. I noted that all the hair and insulating material had broken off the pipes and washed down to the bottom of the casing.

It now becomes necessary to do the following work:

1. Weld riser supply pipe.
2. Re-wrap with new insulating material the riser pipe and steam pipes.
3. Re-case with inside boards and rubberoid paper the boxed casing, and as a matter of better protection, to line the both sides of the boxed casing with zinc or tin, this to prevent water going into this casing and to keep out the wind, as the wood shiplap shrinks and eventually lets in the cold winds of Winter as it was due to the leaking water from the tower and the open cracks in the casing that frost struck the bare pipe with consequent freezing and splitting.

I will make every effort, as stated in my previous letter, to keep the cost as low as is consistent with the big job that has now presented itself.

I think I can suggest that this cost be carried over till your new Fiscal Year, as I feel sure Mr. Plett (approved list), who is doing the work will wait till after April 1st next.

On the completion of this work, I will further report in a general way on other work to be done on this tower, which will also entail considerable expense.

AGENT'S REPORT ON BLOOD AGENCY FOR MONTH OF MAY 1939.

At the Anglican school, the well has been somewhat erratic, the pump having a tendency to pull air a great deal of the time and then again a considerable flow of water will appear, and it may be necessary to pull the pump and check leathers etc and also flow, as we are equipped to test this well if required. The tank due to the breakdowns of late has dried out and it is not possible to get the tank full as there is considerable leakage over the halfway mark, and during the holidays it may be necessary to do some repair work on the tank.

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Sir:

I beg to submit herewith Voucher No. 53, amounting to $320.62, in favour of Mr. F.W. Flatt (Approved List) of Carstairs, for material and labour on the St. Paul's School water tower, when that unit was badly damaged by freezing last Winter, as referred to in my letter of February 17th last.

I may say that while the account exceeds a little my expectation, unforeseen damage and the difficulty of performing this labour, and the material involved to ensure a lasting job, has set the cost somewhat high, but I feel sure that the pipe system to the tank will last quite a few years.

It may be necessary to do some repair work to the tank itself, as the wooden staves at the top of the tank are quite wide from drying out, and it will only hold water to the half way mark.

Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

I have your memorandum of the 19th instant with reference to the expenditure incurred in repairing the water tower at the St. Paul's Indian residential school.

There is a large water tank at this school and the Indian Agent reported in a letter dated February 17, 1939, that an examination of the tank revealed two splits in the riser pipe of the tank. It was, therefore, necessary to strip down the boxed casing of the water riser and steam pipe casing up to the tower. When this was done it was noted that all the hair and insulation material had broken off the pipes and washed down to the bottom of the casing. It was, therefore, necessary to do the following work:

1. Weld riser supply pipe.

2. Re-wrap with new insulating material the riser pipe and steam pipes.

3. Re-case with inside boards and rubberoid paper the boxed casing, and as a matter of better protection, to line the both sides of the boxed casing with zinc or tin, this to prevent water going into this casing and to keep out the wind, as the wood shiplap shrinks and eventually lets in the cold winds of winter as it was due to the leaking water from the tower and the open cracks that frost struck the bare pipe with consequent freezing and splitting.
At the time the Agent wrote there were no funds available for the work but as the school was dependent on the proper condition of the tank for their water it was necessary to authorize the Agent to proceed and forward the account for payment from funds provided in the current year's appropriation. I might add that when forwarding the account on June 31 last Indian Agent Pugh wrote as follows:

"While the account exceeds a little my expectation, unforeseen damage and the difficulty of performing this labour and the material involved to ensure a lasting job has set the cost somewhat high but I feel sure that the pipe system to the tank will last quite a few years."

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

ST. PAUL'S RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Blood Reserve - Cardston, Alberta.

April 20, 1940.

John E. Pugh, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cardston, Alta.

Dear Sir:

In view of the ever increasing demands and growing population of the Reserve, the officials of our Church have decided to further augment the School Staff by the appointment of a well trained and qualified Deaconess, whose sole duty will be to visit and minister to our Anglican Indians on the Reserve.

Further, Inspector Hamilton, during his recent visit and inspection of the Academic work, strongly recommended our engaging an additional teacher for Class Room duty. With the acceptance of the Deaconess, and the similar acceptance and appointment of another teacher in order to cope with the influx of additional students, we shall need more bedrooms in the school than we now possess.

You will recall that we discussed this probability when you were here last week, and on that occasion, I suggested the provision of two additional Staff rooms at convenient and suitable positions in the main building.

Firstly, it is obvious that there two rooms must be provided without delay.

Secondly, the rooms indicated should be at convenient points, where the least possible space be utilized to the best effect.

With that purpose in mind, I sought with your approval the assistance of two local firms to submit estimates for the erection and completion of the necessary quarters.

I am pleased to enclose herewith copies of the estimates now received. These have been carefully checked and examined and both come within the scope of efficient service.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6373, file 764-5, part 7)
I therefore beg to recommend that the estimates be accepted, and that you submit same to the Department with your approval.

I am sure you will agree that with the pressing demands for future development, and barely in order to cope with present emergencies, that it is imperative that suitable and adequate quarters be provided for the increase in personnel of the School Staff. As matters now stand we have no available bedrooms for these two additional workers.

Yours faithfully,

S.H. Middleton
Principal.
Blood Indian Agency,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Residential School,
Alta., May 16th, 1940.

MAY 20 1940

Sir,

I beg to state that the Principal of St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School has taken up with me the matter of providing additional staff rooms at this school, and in this connection I am enclosing a copy of his letter.

In order that the Department may deal with the matter, I have obtained estimates based on the enclosed plans, and it will be noted from the plans, that the changes, or new work, are proposed for the second and top floors of the building.

On the second floor, the plan provides for a partition, and changing a wall in an existing toilet room, and extending this toilet room to accommodate a toilet for the dormitory and one for the staff room. A wash basin in the proposed room is required. The estimated cost of Carpenter work and material for this change is as follows:- Material $45.00, Labour $77.90, and for changes and additional plumbing, the estimated cost is $150.00, inclusive of material and labour.

On the top floor, the plan provides for making two rooms, and bath installation, and the estimated cost of Carpenter work is as follows:- Material $76.50, labour $37.50, and for provision of bath, the estimated cost is $114.00.

The total of this work would be $500.00. The estimates were provided by Mr. T.E.Weston for carpenter work and material, and Mr. F.W.Flett for plumbing fixtures and labour.

For the information of the Department, I am quoting herewith the number of staff employed at this school, and to this total should be added the extra teacher as mentioned in the Principal's letter, who will be taken on the staff in the Fall; Males, white, two males, Indians, two, females, eleven, a total of fifteen resident in the school building proper; Mr. Charles Middleton, who is now designated as the Assistant Principal, is occupying the Farm Instructor's house, and is married with a family.

Respectfully submitted,

Your obedient servant,

J.E.Fugh,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to state that I have recently checked over certain of the equipment at the St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School, which is in need of repair or replacement.

These are enumerated as follows with the approximate cost:

1/ High Pressure Laundry Boiler. Top flues require rebeading and the top sheet requires welding. Approximate cost, $25.00.

2/ Stock watering pump. New jack required as present one is completely worn out. Cost approximately $16.00.

3/ Gurney Oxford Kitchen Range. Right and left sides of fire box castings. Present ones burnt out. Cost approximately $28.00.

4/ My attention is also directed to the water tower at this school, which I note is only holding about half its capacity of water, due to the staves spreading and permitting leaking.

It would appear to me that the only remedy would be to apply a waterproof membrane paint coating on the inside.

I have not obtained an estimate on this work, but will do so if the Department would consider this work.

In view of the curtailment of operating costs, I am submitting this report and would recommend at this time Nos. 1, 2 and 3.

Your obedient servant,

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Sir;

I have the honor to submit herewith Report for the month of December 1940, together with copy of Diary for same month.

SCHOOLS: Both schools have been visited during the month but owing to large amount of Office business to be attended to at this time of year have not made the necessary School report for this month at either school, but hope to be able to make a full report at the end of January.

Authority having been received to repair the floor of the Boy's playroom, this has been done and we expect that the temporary repair will keep the floor in shape for a considerable time. Towards the end of the month the Well at the Blood R C School stopped pumping water, and the tank with the water supply diminishing fast, I advised the Principal to allow the Children to go home until the well had been cleaned out, at the time of writing Authority has been received, to clear the sand out of both the Blood R C School and St Paul's School wells, both of which fill up with sand. At present the St Paul's School are getting enough water for their school needs. As soon as these wells have been cleaned reports will be sent forward under separate cover.

Sir:

I beg to advise that while visiting St Paul's School regarding trouble in the Laundry, I found the following necessary repairs needed, and after considerable discussion with the Principal, regarding the smaller repairs necessary, he agreed to do all the small repairs which were found necessary.

However there were two items which I would be glad to receive authority to replace, which are both in dangerous shape as regards an accident in the Laundry. The main item is the extractor which is in very bad shape, and needs a complete inside (new), the outside of the Extractor is in good shape, but the portion which revolves is the inside is in very poor shape, and Mr Flett Plumber Cardston who accomplished me advises that it is dangerous and may break while in use and portions of it may cause a fatal accident amongst the girls while working in the Laundry.

As this extractor is supplied by the Beaver Laundry Machinery Co Toronto, I thought that if authority is granted for this replacement of the Extractor it could be ordered through our Ottawa Office quicker than writing and getting quotations through this Office. This Extractor is Beaver Laundry Extraxtor Type 244 serial 461. The type figures are badly worn and may not be correct but the serial Number was quite plain. May I be advised if this purchase is being made as early as possible.

The other item is the belting running the main pulley and the belting running the extractor, both these belts are in very bad condition and have been repaired numerous times, one of them having been joined together seven times and is badly worn.

I have asked a quotation from Cardston Motors on the two belts as follows.

1 Belt 4½" 24 feet long, for 30" Pulley
1 Belt 3" 15 feet long for extractor.

Their prices for the two belts is $17.00 subject to change.

May I be advised if I May make this purchase through the Cardston Motors at the above quotation.

Your Obedient Servant

Sir;-

I beg to enclose herewith letter received from Canon Middleton Principal of St Paul's Indian Residential School regarding a new bake oven for this establishment.

I have made enquiries from Mr Flett the Plumber of Cardston, regarding this Bake Oven, and he advises that he has patched this oven for quite a few years and that there is no possibility of making any more repairs, the walls are very thin, the bricks are twisted and cracked, and the flues are in very bad shape.

I beg to advise that while visiting the St. Paul's Indian Residential School with Inspector Schmidt of Calgary, the 500 gallon Hot Water Tank in the Laundry Dept. was found to be leaking at various spots which have already been welded; these are very slow leaks.

I have again visited the School and made a more thorough inspection in company with the Engineer in charge and found that this Tank has already been turned over once to place the original base on top and the fittings changed to accomplish this; this was done on account of leaks that had developed, thus placing the leaky part on the top.

The assistant of the local Plumber who made the last check-up, crawled inside the Tank and reported that the inside of the Tank was badly "pitted" all over and that it was in a dangerous condition.

The Plumber (Mr. F. Flett) advises that these Tanks may be hard to procure but that as he handles the R.C.A.F. Airport contracts, he might be able to get one should the Department decide to purchase same.

This Tank, in its present state is very apt to give way at any time and an emergency would arise which would take time to rectify. I am therefore bringing the matter to the attention of the Department so that this possibility may be forestalled.

May I have the Department's instructions regarding a replacement? This is a 500 gal. Hot Water Tank, type B 468 of Craner Limited, when taken down it may also necessitate the replacement of the Steam Coil.

Your obedient servant,

**CANADA**
Extract from Inspector Schmidt's report on the St. Paul's Indian Residential School dated February 10, 1942.

BUILDINGS

The buildings are in fair condition. A few repairs are needed here and there.

Rain, sleet and snow, driven by winds, penetrate into the west end gables of the dormitories which is spoiling the plaster. I believe the coping stones are loose, and need to be re-cemented together; or renewed with a solid layer of concrete; perhaps an asphalt compound or mixture would serve the purpose. I have asked for a report, in writing, re this matter.

The metal (copper) covered wash tables, or troughs, in both the boys' and girls' wash-rooms, are perforating through wear. This should be renewed at an early date, as water is now leaking onto the floors. Tin or galvanized iron is not suitable; it always looks black and dirty. I am wondering whether a cement (concrete) trough, having a very finely polished (glazed) finish, would not serve the purpose; I have never seen anything like this, but if we could get the same finish as there is on the cement floor of the playrooms in the basement, which is polished like glass, I would be satisfied to recommend it.

The bake oven is in poor condition -- badly burned. It might be possible to repair it; new grates were asked for in the estimates. The Principal suggests a new one.

The hot water tank is perforated, and needs to be renewed. This has been asked for and approved. (Ref. Dept. #103-1-5 dated Jan. 28, 1942).
The main water tank -- an elevated wooden structure, outside the building -- (gravity system) is said to be showing signs of wear and tear, owing to the elements. This may cause trouble by leaking, before long. Being a poor "steeple-jack" I did not try to climb up to look at it closely, but I asked for a full report on same.

This school has no frigidaire, and they are very anxious to obtain one. They are still using ice, which is not very satisfactory. This is hauled from Lee's Creek, 6 miles away, and cannot be obtained in square blocks, as the weather is too mild to freeze it thick. A brick-walled frigidaire could easily be built adjoining the west wall of the kitchen; this should have two compartments: one for meats, the other for dairy produce. A small fish compartment (drawer) could also be installed.

The following is a description of the Tanks:

Old Tank:
Badly pitted and for which new one is purchased, is a 500 Gallon Hot Water Tank, Type B468 of Crane's Ltd., with a Man-hole and Pipe Coil. Tank is 36" wide and 10' long and has a Man-hole and pipe coil for Heating purposes, this coil is used for heating water in the Tank from the Heating system in conjunction with jacket heater.

New Tank:
Tank now supplied by the Riverside Iron Works, Calgary, is 42" wide and 8' long and has no man-hole, it will be impossible to heat this boiler except through the jacket heater direct.

Mr. F.W. Flett has made a report on this Tank, a copy of which is enclosed. He quotes, over and above the installation fee, the question of making a man-hole and installing an Iron pipe coil such as was in use in the old tank, at the sum of $100.00.

This other recommendation (if the necessary permission can be obtained from the Dept. of Munitions & Supply) is to place a Copper Coil Element, which would be expanded into a removable head through a steel sleeve, welded in the Tank, thus doing without a man-hole and having a coil that would easily be cleaned off as corrosion would only be on the outside of the coil, which, being cleaned off, would be as good as new and would last indefinitely as copper does not...
not deteriorate. This type, furnished and installed would cost $125.00.

The total cost on this basis would be, installation of Tank, provide and install Man-hole and Steel Coil $220.00, for Installation of Tank and furnishing and installing a removable type Copper Heating Element at $245.00.
