Re: Wooden water tank (Tower), St. Paul's
Indian Residential School, Cardston, Alta.

Sir:

As per your request of Feb. 26th, I beg to advise the following in regard to the above subject matter.

An inspection of this Tank and Tower was made by Mr. Ralph Weston on our recent visit to the St. Paul's School and he advises me as follows.

A complete tightening of all rods, packing joints and purchasing the necessary nuts to tighten the rods, caulking of all cracks and the bottom of the Tank and a complete check, for the sum of $75.00 (Seventy-Five Dollars).

Mr. Weston however, advises me that this work should give very satisfactory results and that he is prepared to guarantee the work if the School authorities will fill the Tank to capacity and keep it up to that level.

He advises me also that at no time does the water go above a level of 6' (Six Feet) or water, this fails to keep the Tank soaked and the upper portion naturally dries out.

I have brought this to the attention of the School Principal, and explained that the responsibility for keeping the Tower and Tank in shape is in their hands and that I am advising the Dept. accordingly that, if this work is done, they, the School authorities, will have to keep the water to a maximum height to prevent a repetition of the trouble.

Jan. 6, 1944.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Further to your recent letter regarding Fire-hazard, As stated before all the fire hose of this school has been in use since completion of the building in 1924. That is twenty years ago, and the hose in the meantime has become more or less perished, and does not hold water.

The fire extinguishers now attached on all corridors and stairways have also been on hand for several years and need replenishing.

Would further suggest that a complete fire-hydrant be built adjoining the Water tower with at least 500 feet of hose attached. Such could be used for any outside purpose with efficient force. I made this suggestion several years ago, but was informed there were no funds available for that purpose.

In addition to our regular series of Fire-drills the equipment mentioned above, would strongly fortify our position.

Yours faithfully,

S.H.M./MJ.
Principal.

Ottawa,
January 11, 1944.

Mr. A. McMillan, Indian Agent, Cardston, Alta.

As you are aware, we recently forwarded a circular letter to the principals of all residential schools in connection with taking precautions against fire hazards. A letter has just been received from Reverend Canon Middleton which reads, in part, as follows:

"As stated before all the fire hose of this school has been in use since completion of the building in 1924. That is twenty years ago, and the hose in the meantime has become more or less perished, and does not hold water.

"The fire extinguishers now attached on all corridors and stairways have also been on hand for several years and need replenishing.

"Would further suggest that a complete fire-hydrant be built adjoining the water tower with at least 500 feet of hose attached. Such could be used for any outside purpose with efficient force. I made this suggestion several years ago, but was informed there were no funds available for that purpose.

"In addition to our regular series of fire-drills the equipment mentioned above would strongly fortify our position."

If you let me know the number and size of the fire extinguishers at present in the building immediate arrangements can be made to secure refills for them.
In regard to the suggestion for a complete fire hydrant adjoining the water tower you might let me know if you think this is absolutely necessary and, if so, give an estimate of its cost. Purchase of the amount of hose suggested by the Principal would involve an expenditure between $250.00 and $275.00.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
January 11, 1944.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to our recent circular in regard to fire hazards. The Indian Agent is being written and requested to advise us the number and size of the fire extinguishers at present in the school in order that we may purchase refills for them. We have also brought to his attention your suggestion regarding a fire hydrant and he is being requested to submit quotations for our consideration.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Indian Affairs Branch Dept of Mines & Resources Ottawa.

Attention Philip Phelan Esqr.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th inst., in which you quote from Canon Middletons letter in part, in reply to your circular to the School Principals re taking precautions against Fire hazard in the Residential Schools.

I have made a close inspection of both Schools in regard to the present state of the Fire Hose in each School. In St Paul's School I found nine Fire Hoses in the Corridors and the Boiler Room, every one of these hoses were very old and in a bad state of repair. At St Mary's R C School I found 10 Hoses some of them in a very excellent state, which had been replaced lately, and the rest of the hoses were in a good condition. I t would seem that the fire hoses in St Pauls should be replaced immediately for to give them fair protection inside; I would also recommend that sufficient refills be purchased for the fire extinguishers at each School the number and size of each extinguisher being attached on a separate sheet.

In reply to your last paragraph regarding the suggestion of a Hydrant being placed close to the water tower for outside fire protection, I have looked over the situation regarding this suggestion, and find that the site of the new compound to the suggested Hydrant will be laying on the ground and will hardly reach the main Building. I would like to recommend that when funds are available to insure good protection to the School that can be used when the building is full of smoke the following which I have tried to show on the enclosed sketch, as both building are very much alike the same system can be used at both Schools.

The plan is as follows the running of a three inch pipe to the North and South Walls of the annex to the main Building where at present the Kitchen Laundry and Boiler room are located, with the School Chapel above, which is the most likely place for a fire to start, the three inch pipe will come through the wall and be fitted with a connection to which the fire hose can be attached. This will allow the use of the hose on the back of the main building, and will cover a portion of the front of the building. The expense to do this with the purchase of three inch pipe sufficient to reach the walls from the main water main, the labor (this may be done with help of the School engineer) and the purchase of 300 Feet of Fire Hose for each School.

I have made no estimate of the cost of this work, but if the Department approve of my suggestion I will immediately make enquiries as to cost etc.

Copy to Inspector G P Schmidt
Alberta Inspectorate
507 Public Building
Calgary.

Mr. A. McMillan, Indian Agent, Cardston, Alta.

With reference to your letter of the 26th ultimo, I am requesting the Purchasing Agent to secure 6 - 1 qt. fire extinguishers and a case of refills for these extinguishers for the St. Paul's Indian Residential School.

With reference to the Blood School, I am not certain if you mean that 5 gallons of Pyrene liquid for refills is required or whether you intended to state that this quantity is on hand.

We have carefully reviewed your suggestion regarding hydrants and it is quite possible that this would provide considerable additional fire protection. At the present time we have no funds available for the purpose and in addition suitable hose is difficult to obtain. However, you might make further inquiries with a view to advising us definitely regarding the expenditure that would be required to effect this improvement at both of the schools.

I also note from your letter that you consider the fire hose in the interior of the St. Paul's School should be replaced, but you do not give any information regarding the length and size of the hose required. Please let me hear from you in this regard and an order will be placed. At the same time you should state how many couplings will be necessary.

St. Paul's Indian Residential School.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 28th ultimo, in which you intimate that an account has been presented by Mr. F. W. Flett, Cardston, Alberta, covering two items of expense at the school, for which apparently no authority had been received at this office.

Inasmuch as the repairs to the pumping system involve a comparatively small amount ($22.82), it will be in order for you to send forward a voucher for this sum. In the absence of Mr. Phelan, however, I am somewhat puzzled with respect to the purchase and installation of the bake oven at a cost of $120.50. Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to state with reference to Purchase Order #1640, File #57418-15-16 dated March 13th, 1945 to John Woslyng of Cardston, Alta., for the supply and installation of a 5 HP Electric Motor - 3 Phase at the St. Paul's Anglican Residential School, that with Mr. Woslyng, this job was looked over, and on the advice of Mr. Woslyng, it is now asked that the Purchase Order be cancelled for the time being, as it is found that a 3 Phase will not work on the present set up of the Calgary Power Co., that only a Single Phase will work in this type of line.

The cost of a Single Phase is higher than a 3 Phase, but Mr. Woslyng advises that the present set up at this school is not a good working layout. The 5 HP Motor at present in use is entirely overlooked, and the Motor is in bad shape, due to overloading.

It is now suggested that a re-arrangement of this set up be made, details and cost of which will be submitted after prices on the suggested change have been obtained and compiled.

It is regretted that we have had to take this action, but it is considered that the Department should review the proposed redistribution of the Machinery load at the School as will be outlined by Mr. Woslyng, before going any further in the purchase of the Motor authorized in P.O. #1640, and it was therefore thought advisable to cancel this Purchase Order for this Fiscal Year of 1944-45, and the matter reviewed for Fiscal Year 1945-46, Estimates.

J. E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING JUNE 30th, 1945, ON BLOOD INDIAN AGENCY

WELFARE AND TRAINING.

SCHOOLS. Both schools well attended during the quarter, except for truants. The services of the RCMP used in some instances for the return of pupils who either ran away or did not return from week-end holidays.

The matter of the above truancy is now being dealt with on instructions from the Branch, and the notations of the Provincial School Inspector's Report being passed on to the respective Principals for their comments.

A number of pupils were hospitalized during the quarter at the Indian Hospital and returned to their respective schools on recovering.

Quarantine was placed on both schools during the month June due to an outbreak of measles, nine cases were reported from the St. Paul's Anglican School, none from the Blood R.C. School.

Premises at both schools are in fairly good shape, and improvements made at both schools without cost to the Department from appropriations. Painting of several buildings at The Blood R.C. School has been carried out, and are quite attractive, using white for walls and red for roofs.

The Painting of the barns and house at the St. Paul's School has been completed, this was delayed due to bad weather.

The High Pressure Laundry Boiler was the subject of Special letter seeking authority for repairs by the Lethbridge Laundry. Due to labour shortage, this work cannot be carried out till after the 9th of July, when this company will have a boiler man available.

The Motor at this school, used for pumping and laundry was sent into Lethbridge for repairs, and is now in use again. Further study of the plant at this school is being made, with a view to eliminating the costs of repair, and will be submitted to the Branch when compiled.

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I beg to state that the Principal of the St. Paul's Anglican Indian Res. School reported to this Office that one of the main Heating Boilers was leaking in the Tubes, I accordingly examined this Boiler and thought it advisable to have a competent Boilermaker examine same.

Mr. G. B. Davis was consulted by Telephone on the matter and he had his expert examine both Boilers, and he found two Flues leaking due to "pitting", and advised against replacing these as a number of other Tubes were weak and replacement would cause further leaking and he has recommended re-Tubing the Boiler completely.

The Boilers in this School have been in use for twenty years, and no repair work on Tubes carried out, and in view of this Mr. Davis made the above recommendation and a copy of Mr. Davis's letter is attached, outlining the costs for this job, this being $496.25.

It is possible that the second Boiler will be weakening, and it is therefore recommended that the above be repaired at once, in case of Flues going bad in the other Boiler.

The writer is of the opinion that if a "Stoker" was provided at this School, using only one Boiler, which method is being used at the Blood R. C. School, and it is found there, that one Boiler is sufficient to heat the school under ordinary conditions. This is only a suggestion, with a view to saving a re-Fluing job on the second Boiler and no data has been obtained on the cost of the purchase of an Automatic Stoker and installation, but it is thought that this cost would approximate $600.00.

However, the matter of re-Tubing the Boiler now leaking, is urgent, should the other one spring a Tube leak the School would then be without heat.

The arrangements mentioned in Mr. Davis's letter regarding Transportation, Board and Room has been tentatively arranged with the Principal of the School, may we be advised, please.

J. E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Complying with your request we have had our boilermaker inspect the boiler at the St. Paul's Anglican School and are of the opinion that to replace two leaking tubes at this time would prove a matter of throwing good money after bad.

The engineer intimated that the boilers had been in service for about twenty years and had so far not been re-tubed. This suggests to us that all tubes may be pitted and such works as would be required to replace those presently giving you trouble might disturb the others to such an extent that they also would shortly commence to show leaks.

Due to the fact that the smoke box end of the boiler is so very close to the solid brick basement wall, it will be necessary to cut these tubes in two inside the boiler and remove them through the upper manhole. Taking allowance for this and the complete re-tubing of your boiler we are pleased to quote you a price of $496.25.

In addition to the above charges we would have to depend on you to see that our boilermaker and helper, together with their personal tools, were picked up in Cardston and delivered back at that point on completion of the work. We would also depend on you supplying these two men with room and board during the time they are working on the boiler and which we would estimate would run in the neighbourhood of ten days.

We appreciate this opportunity of quoting you. Should we be favoured with your order, it is hoped we would commence work on these repairs within possibly one week of receipt of same.

Sincerely yours,

I beg to state that the condition of the Pumping Unit, Motor and Laundry operation at The St Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School has been causing some concern for the school management.

At present the pumping is carried out by a Single Phase motor of 5HP, through a drive shaft to the Pump head, and this same motor also runs the drive shaft for the laundry machinery. This causes overloading on the motor, and to add to the load the Pump head is badly worn, and has passed its efficiency peak.

In view of the foregoing, the writer had Mr John Wosley of Cardston, check over this plant with the Blockman of the Fairbanks Morse Co Ltd of Calgary, with a view to submitting the matter to the Branch with a detailed costs.

The details procured are as follows:

WELFARE AND TRAINING:

SCHOOLS. Schools re-opened on the 2nd of September, and were visited on the 4th to check attendance. As a result of such visit and lack of attendance, the Branch were advised by wire of the status of attendance, and instructions sought.

On receipt of these instructions, truant notices were prepared, and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police requested to serve such notices. This latter action was the subject of correspondence with the Branch.

The schools have been visited each week during September, and at the last visit, 19 pupils were absent from The Blood RG School and 50 pupils absent from the St. Paul's Anglican School, this information was passed along to the Branch in my Letter No. 402-11B of the 25th instant.

Some 6 pupils are in the USA, with their parents who have gone there for work and visits, and truant notices were mailed to Min. F. Chief P. Chreighton who is also in the USA, and he was asked to serve such notices.

There has developed a very distinct feeling among a lot of the Indian parents against sending their children to school, and seek devious means to attain that end. The Medical Officer has been requested by your Agent to exercise great care in giving out certificates of health to parents. A number have called on the Doctor, seeking exemption for their children.

Both schools have been advised that no monthly or other holidays are to be given during the school term, and the letter sent out to the Principals from the Branch, have been posted for the Indians benefit.

A survey was made at the Blood RG School in connection with the re-conditioning of the Dining room floors, and the Branch's letter in this respect has now been received.

Both schools were in very good shape for the start of the School year, in both cases painting and cleaning of floors at some expense to the schools having been carried out.

At the St. Pauls' Anglican School, the leaking of one of the heating boilers was reported, and consequent upon this report, the Southbridge Iron works, were requested to examine this boiler; they report that two flues are leaking, and a re-tubing job is stated to be the only satisfactory way of re-conditioning. This

(over)
matter is being dealt with by special letter.

Data has also been obtained regarding the pumping arrangements at this school, and this also will be dealt with by letter.

During the quarter ending, some 15 pupils of the Blood RC school and 6 of the St. Paul's school were hospitalized, and returned to their respective schools. These children were sent to hospital for varying reasons, minor accidents and ill health, none of which were serious.

Correspondence was entered into with the Branch, regarding a pupil of the Blood RC School, requesting permission at the Father's request, to place this pupil in the Minapore Orphanage School. The contents of the Dept. reply was given to Shade, and I am now informed that the child is in attendance at that school and Shade is desirous of re-opening the correspondence in the matter of grant for this child.

AGENCY'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31ST, 1946.

Welfare And Training

School attendance improved during the quarter, mostly as a result of invoking the truancy section of the Indian Act.

The total roll for the St Paul's School at the end of the quarter is 136 enrolled, of these 20 failed to attend due to illness or truancy, the latter embraced 11 students of which 5 were in the USA, not having returned after the summer holidays.

One has been excused school by the Medical Officer as not fit for attendance.

At the Blood R.C. School, the total enrolled number pupils is 176, of these 5 failed to attend during the quarter due to illness.

New admissions for the quarter are as follows:

Blood R.C. School. 20. St Paul Ang School. 1.

Discharges for the quarter are, Blood R.C., and St Paul's. 2.

Visits have been made to both schools during the quarter and matter pertaining to the welfare of the children gone into with the Principals. Both institutions are well kept, and the children appear fairly contented, though there exists a feeling among the pupils in regard to the holidays which they formerly enjoyed.

The heating boiler at the St Paul's School was re-tubed and a very satisfactory job carried out, this boiler is in full use and the engineer in charge advises that it is working well.

The matter of the Pumping system at the above school was the subject of special correspondence, and it is hoped that the new pump head will be forthcoming in the new year.

The SHP Electric Motor in use on the old unit, went out of use completely at the end of the quarter and had to be sent to Calgary for repairs, this will be the subject of special letter on receipt of information as to costs of re-conditioning this motor. The Gas engine is being used for pumping purposes and keeping the lighting equipment. The Principal of this school also brought to my attention the condition of the Water tower, which I noted is leaking; but due to icing conditions we have been unable to get into the tower to examine the difficulty. However it does appear that the Radiators have been disconnected and will have to be re-installed, and the leak in the water tank repaired. A further report will be made when costs are available.

The work of draining the area adjacent to the basement of the Blood R.C. School was completed by the Parks Branch, this was carried out under difficulties due to the lateness of the season, and the inability of obtaining equipment.

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Re: Pump Repairs - St. Paul's Ang. Ind. Res. School.

I beg to submit herewith Voucher #227 in favour of F. W. Flett, Plumber, CALGARY, Alta., amounting to $53.70 for repairs to the Plumbing system at the St. Paul's Indian Res. School, this Agency.

In this connection it is desired to state that no water could be procured from this well, and I had the pump drawn out and it was found that the working barrel was worn through and one length of pipe pitted and beyond use and leaking.

As the main pump in the School proper was in process of being installed, no water was available and I therefore authorized the repairs as indicated on the enclosed Voucher, as being of an emergent nature.

I may also state that when mounting the new Fairbanks-morse Pump Head and Motor, that we found that the working barrel and Pump Rods in this well were in need of repair. The working barrel was sent to Calgary by Mr. John Woslyng, this necessitated pulling the lengths of pipe and Rods out, which was done after the new Rod had been installed and it was found that the Rod and Valve would not drop and water was leaking out, cutting down the flow of water in the head. The inspection of the Cylinder & Rod revealed the badly worn condition and I instructed Mr. Woslyng to carry out the necessary repairs of having the Cylinder Barrel honed, the foot valve re-built and re-made and leathers supplied, we replaced the 4 Rods but these are warped and drag on the pipe sides causing excessive power to be used on the Pump Head.

I personally checked over the whole system with Mr. John Woslyng and authorized the repairs, and have further requested Mr. Woslyng to procure new Pump Rods and these will be installed as soon as received.

It is estimated that the cost of repairs to the Main Pump will approximate $150.00 to $175.00, which will cover 4 New Rods & Couplings approx. $45.00 - Honing Cylinder $12.50 - Making Foot Valve, new Leathers, and labour entailed pulling Rods and replacing in Well.

I may add that it was when the Main Pump was out in the School, that the Stock Pump broke down and no water was available hence my treating the matter as emergent and authorizing the necessary repairs for both pumps.

I may add that while generally checking over at this School I was informed that the Water Tower Tank was in very poor condition, and that it will only hold approximately 11000 Gals of water due to shrinking of the leaves and warped condition of the Tank and it therefore appear that the Pressure Tank system recommended for this School by the Engineering Branch, Banff (Mr. Snelson) be installed at an early date.

Respectfully submitted, and I trust that my action will be concurred in.

I beg to state that while checking up attendance at the St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential School on the 4th inst., several matters pertaining to the School premises were brought to my attention - these are enumerated herewith:

2. SEWER SYSTEM - This has become bogged down due to lack of water passing through the system while the Pumping set up was under repair, and it appears necessary to have the system and septic tank pumped out while flushing with the Fire hose. To do this I have obtained the services of the Town of Cardston tank pump which we will have to pay a nominal rental for 2 days, and authorized the School to hire 2 Indians to assist the School labour in this work.

It is thought that if the whole Tank is cleaned out in this manner, it will clear the blockage and prevent the recurrence of the strong odour now permeating the School.

I have not obtained costs for the Roof work as this will be difficult to estimate, being a patching job, utilizing tin flashing some shingles and perhaps some sealing Compound. Should the Board so desire an Estimate can be obtained from a local Contractor and submitted prior to carrying out this work. It is thought that approximately $125.00 would cover the Roof work and Plastering.

In the matter of the Sewer Tank cleaning, if, as I surmise, in using the Town Pump and Indian labour will clear this Tank, a sum of $25.00 should cover this work. As this work is urgent and essential to School health, I am proceeding with this work.

October 30, 1946.

Mr. Hoey

Re: St. Paul's Indian Residential School Blood Indian Agency, Cardston, Alberta.

An inspection of the elevated tank and water distribution system at the above school has been made by engineers of this branch in accordance with your request of June 28, 1946.

The existing tank and supporting structure has deteriorated to such an extent that it has become unsafe and uneconomical to repair. A careful study has been made of the water requirements for this school and it is recommended that a 2500 Imperial gallon water pressure tank be installed to take the place of the elevated tank, the estimated cost of which would be $3000-including the cost of dismantling the elevated tank. The water pressure on the top floor is at present only 15 p.s.i. The minimum pressure with the proposed system would be 40 to 50 p.s.i., thus ensuring adequate fire protection which the school does not have now. The cost of replacing the elevated tank and supporting structure would be approximately $12,000 with an additional $1200 required for a gasoline driven centrifugal booster pump for use in case of fire.

We now have all the necessary information to enable us to proceed with the installation of the pressure tank system at once if you concur in our recommendation. It is estimated that this work will require about two months as this is the best delivery that can be procured for the steel tank. On the other hand replacement of the present elevated tank would require about six months.

We will await your further advice before proceeding any further in this matter.

Director.

Memorandum:

To - C. M. Walker, Res.,
District Engineer.

St. Paul's Indian Residential School,
Cardston, B.C.

I arrived at this school Monday morning May 19th, 1947 at 9:30 A.M. O'Sullivan's dragline and crew of three men arrived at the same time. About noon a large truck arrived loaded with an air compressor and jack hammers. By 5 P.M., excavation had been completed and the large tank placed in position in the excavation.

May 20th. All piping connections from the tank, through the concrete wall and into the boiler room were made, and excavation refilled with earth. Surplus earth was hauled away where required by school officials.

May 21st. Plumber and helper completed inside piping and change over from old to new tanks. Electricians installed pressure switch, conduit, wiring, etc.

May 22nd. I rented a small air compressor for initial air charge into tank and spent day checking and adjusting controls.

The large tank was installed in the only location on the outside of the boiler room basement wall not occupied by coal bins, ash hoist or chimney foundation. In this location, at a depth of six feet below ground surface, 6" piping from the pump to the outside tank was installed. This line crossed the trench at such an angle that it was necessary to place the end of the tank at a distance of twelve feet from the outside boiler room wall so that the bottom of the tank could be set at an elevation of eight feet below ground surface. It was not advisable to cut the 4" pipe as it was at the time under pressure supplying water to school. The tank will have an additional winter cover of some two feet of ashes and cinders from the boilers.

It is necessary that the 1½ H.P. motor that is now running the pump be replaced by a 3 H.P. motor in order that the tank could be maintained at the required 85 pound pressure if and when the water surface in the well was down to 150 feet. In my report of August 6th, 1946, page 2, under "Well" I stated that the motor was 2 H.P. At that time the 2 H.P. motor was on hand and ready for installation. However, on my inspection trip of May 19th, 1947 I found that the pump was being driven by a ¾ horse power motor. The 2 H.P. motor had, for some reason or other, not been installed.

The 1½ H.P. motor now installed would raise the water pressure in the new tank to only 50 p.s.i. This condition, which will probably obtain until a more powerful motor is installed, made it necessary to temporarily set the automatic controls to a pressure range of between 34 and 48 p.s.i.

Re: Water Tank at St. Paul's School,
Blood Indian Reserve, Cardston, Alberta.

On September 23rd this office received a phone call from the Indian Agent of the above reserve to the effect that the recently installed pressure tank had settled, breaking a connection in one of the pipes between the tank and the inside of the building. The Agent was instructed to have the local plumber repair the break and leave the work open for our inspection.

Mr. Snelsom inspected this work on October 3rd. All the run-off from an adjacent roof, and from a two foot depth of wet snow directly over the tank, had caused sufficient settlement in the tank and in the one inch air pipe leading from the tank into the building to break the threads off the one inch pipe at the tank. Upon inspection it was found that they had dug down to this connection and repaired it. They were advised to fill in the hole, as in Mr. Snelsom's opinion it would not be probable that there would be any further settlement. There is also the possibility of there being a weak thread in the connection that broke.

In our opinion very little settlement could have occurred in the large 5,000 gallon tank as this tank was carefully bedded down on the solid earth of a newly excavated trench. Some settlement could have occurred in the one inch air pipe that runs from the top of the tank to the inside of the building.

On October 3rd the old water tower had been pulled down and a local firm was salvaging the useable lumber and pipe.

C. M. Walker,
Supervising Engineer.

Attention: Bernard F. Neary, Superintendent of Education.

We have your letter of the 10th instant, File 103-1-5 (F.1) with reference to purchasing a building to be used for the Farming Instructor at the St. Paul's Residential School on the Blood Reserve.

The necessity of a building for the Farming Instructor is not disputed, and is rather urgent at this School; at the present time the married Instructor must live in a room inside the school proper, which is inadequate and very unsatisfactory.

I have viewed the building suggested, however, and certainly do not consider it a 'bargain'. It is only a shell and when moved would be of little value; the shingles are all coming off, the windows are out and although the building is double-boarded it has no outside sheeting. The chimney is of the bracket type, and would have to be rebuilt if moved; the inside is hopeless being used at the moment for the storage of grain.

St. Paul's School has a qualified Carpenter on the Staff and a goodly number of large Indian boys anxious to learn more about carpentry - it would be my earnest recommendation that the Department furnish these boys with the material and, under the guidance of Mr. J. Mould, the Instructor, allow them to build a small cottage for the Farming Instructor. The Principal has assured me that the Staff and pupils can handle all the labour involved. I have had an estimate prepared by the Cahoon Lumber Company of Cardston for the entire material for a small cottage, 20 x 20, or 16 x 20 with an 8 x 10 lean-to copy of which I enclose; you will see that the total cost of material is not much greater than the cost of moving the ramshackle building and the value will be thrice as great.
Mr. B.F. Neary

I believe the Department would have plans for a simple cottage, size 20 x 20, which Mr. Mould could follow - if not, I am sure plans can be drawn here for such a building.

The estimate enclosed includes everything for the cottage from cement foundation, chimney, shingles and siding and is complete. There would be an extra cost - in either plan of moving or building - of electric lights and plumbing, but the total cost would not come to over $1,000.00 - including all material, electricity and plumbing for kitchen and bath.

I would sincerely recommend that the bill of material, as listed on the enclosed estimate, be purchased for the St. Paul's School for the purpose of erecting a small cottage for the Farming Instructor on the understanding that the Staff of the School do all labour necessary without cost to the Department.

R.D. Regan,
Superintendent.

Dear Archdeacon Cook:

On receipt of your letter of the 7th ultimo with reference to a cottage for the farm instructor at the St. Paul's Indian Residential School, the Indian Superintendent was written and his reply reads in part as follows,

"I have viewed the building suggested, however, and certainly do not consider it a 'bargain'. It is only a shell and when moved would be of little value; the shingles are all coming off, the windows are out and although the building is double-boarded it has no outside sheeting. The chimney is of the bracket type, and would have to be rebuilt if moved; the inside is hopeless being used at the moment for the storage of grain."

In view of the above, the Department does not consider it advisable to proceed with the purchase of the building mentioned.

As an alternative, the Superintendent suggests the erection of a small cottage, the material for which would be supplied by the Department and the labour would be supplied by the school management. The latter would include the manual training teacher and the larger boys. To follow out this suggestion would involve an expenditure of approximately $1,000, and I regret that at the present time we do not have the funds for the purpose. However, the Superintendent's recommendation will receive further consideration after April 1st.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Your files 103-2-5 and 103-1-5 (Z).

Upon receipt of yours of the 24th instant, I contacted the Manager of the War Assets Corporation, Calgary, and learned that his office had just received a directive to say that Building #12 at Peace and Building #38 at Macleod have been allocated to the Indian Affairs Branch, and would be released when notification of payment for them had been received.

I have not yet contacted Superintendent Ragan, but I know that the moving tenders do not include the placing of the foundations. This work must be done either by day labour or by contract when weather conditions allow. I would not recommend that such work be done until the weather at least is fine and warm, and that will be in the new fiscal year. It is not at all likely that the mover will get the buildings on to the reserve before early summer.

In the meantime, the foundations can be made. (I have moved numerous buildings and set them up in the air until the foundations were laid. This is not the best procedure, of course.)

In regard to the changes to be made to these buildings, I cannot remember how the windows are placed, but I would not attempt to do any alterations until they are on the new foundations. Will not fenestration be subject to the direction the front is facing, and whether or not they are clear of other large buildings? I also consider it too early to consult with an Engineer from the Lands and Development service.

I am asking Mr. Ragan to locate the sites for these buildings and to obtain some figures on cost of foundations, to be submitted to you.

The main problem now is to gain possession of the buildings and, in due course, get them moved on to the Reserve. We cannot expect to have them in use before next fall.

Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

We were called down to the St. Paul's Residential School, Blood Reserve, yesterday where the water supply has failed. I immediately called Hall Brothers, plumbers of Cardston, who, after pulling the rods, reported that there was no water in the well. Wm. Maughan, Well Driller of Lethbridge was then called and reported that a new well would have to be drilled.

Mr. Maughan stated that he cleaned this well out in March 1941 and at that time stated that the well might last five weeks and might last five years, but that a new well should be drilled soon. The casing was very thin and pitted at that time and he expected it to give way at any time; that is what has happened now and, according to Mr. Maughan, there is no remedy but a new well. See Mr. MacMillan's correspondence on his accompanying Voucher No. 408 of March 7, 1941.

The present well is 144 feet deep and Mr. Wm. Maughan quotes a price of $2.00 per foot for drilling a new well and $2.00 per foot for 6" casing - until his present casing is used up and after that $2.25 per foot for casing - he believes however that he has enough casing for this well at $2.00. This well driller cannot get to this job until around the 19th instant but has promised to come as soon as possible if authority is granted for a new well.

May this be treated as urgent and authority given for the expenditure of approximately $600.00 for the drilling of a new well at this school. An Air Mail reply would be appreciated.

Mr. R.D. Ragan, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Cardston, Alberta.

Please find attached a copy of the report submitted by the Nutrition Division of the Department of National Health and Welfare upon the St. Paul's Indian Residential School.

You will note that the sanitary and hygienic conditions are very clean and tidy and that the food quality is good. The report shows that the foods are suitably prepared and cooked for immediate service. If the family service system were introduced here, it is felt that a great improvement could be made.

A copy of this report has been sent to the M.S.C.C. and will be forwarded to the principal of this school in the near future. When you have ascertained that his report has arrived would you please discuss this matter at some length with him and forward your comments to the Department for action.

It would seem that the main problem at this school is the provision of an adequate dough mixer.

(Signed) Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
could it would not be feasible from the standpoint of training or convenience. I have written, under separate cover, regarding the immediate need of a bake oven and have forwarded a requisition for same together with prices and literature from General Steel Wares Ltd., of Calgary, who claim to be able to supply in four months time. It is hoped that an oven can be ordered immediately and that the present relic will hang together until delivery can be made.

Bread mixer. This is certainly needed - the work of mixing great quantities of dough is far too great for the pupils and even the grown staff. We hope to have a greatly increased attendance at this school in the new term and a mixer will then be an absolute necessity. It would be very desirable if a bread mixer could be installed at the same time the new oven is put in this school - the two should certainly go together and make for more efficient production with much less manual labor.

Potato Peeler. A potato peeler should be secured for this school and would be another big labor saver. We should be able to secure a suitable peeler from War Assets; I shall look into this the next time I am in Calgary and report. It would be appreciated also if War Assets at Ottawa could be interviewed regarding any of these machines which might be for sale.

Walk-in Refrigerator. A necessity which has been brought to the attention of the Department and turned down in the past. For sanitation and health and for the convenience of the Staff, a walk-in refrigerator should be installed in the near future.

Bread slicer. We should be able to secure this machine, inexpensively, from War Assets along with the potato peeler, - it will be a great help and should not cost much. Could War Assets, Ottawa, be approached regarding a bread slicer - when information is asked re the potato peeler; I shall see what is in Calgary stores.

Electric Mixer: A household type mixer is what Miss McCready suggests - not a necessity, but very useful nevertheless. One can be secured locally for approximately $50.00.

Covering of Table Tops. There are twenty tables in the dining room of this school, each 8' x 3\(\frac{1}{2}\)', making a total of 560 sq. ft. of table surface to be covered; at the same time we would
need approximately 500' of aluminum beading for the edges. These tables are badly worn and should be covered with either battleship linoleum or tempered masonite; the masonite, I believe, makes the neatest and most durable surface as well as being most economical. With pupils of the school doing the work, under the able direction of their woodworking instructor, this whole project could be completed for about $250.00, if authority were given.

While we are discussing tables, I would like to see the 'family service' system inaugurated at this school. This system is used at our other Residential School and with very marked success. With this method the children get their food served hot, they take only what they can eat which makes for a considerable saving, and at the same time learn valuable table manners. This method also makes for a neater dining room and I am sure the pupils enjoy it much more in that each table is one little happy family rather than the long tables stretching across the room, without any individuality, where the food is placed on the plates in the kitchen and brought to the table - cold when eaten. Miss McCready, in her report, mentions this system and I am sure would like to see it started.

The tables that we now have could be used, if repaired, as individual tables, but some form of chairs would have to be secured - and the benches that are now used thrown out. We would also need covered serving dishes for each table.

If the Department would consider starting this system of dining at the St. Paul's School, I would be only too glad to secure complete prices on all necessary items.

Covering of floors. The kitchen floor in this school is of cement - it should be covered with linoleum for the Staff's sake; however, with the scarcity of this item it is believed that this will have to wait for the present.

Additions of necessary cooking utensils. Additions of large kettles and mixing bowls, as recommended by Miss McCready, have been purchased by the Principal and are now in use.

Dishwashing unit. This was asked for last year - at a cost of $950.00, but funds at that time did not warrant the purchase. We mean to ask for this item at the beginning of the coming fiscal year again - as it is badly needed - and we hope that purchase can be effected at that time.
In closing, we would like to point out that the St. Paul's Residential School - as a structure - is badly run down. This is due in part to age and also to the lack of upkeep during the war years. The roof, of course, is the big thing and the leakage caused by it has been instrumental in doing a great deal of damage to the interior walls and ceilings. Some plastering is now badly needed and the entire building, inside and out, needs paint in the worst way. The water system has not been working perfectly, and the last blow has been the failure of the well, which has given out (authority has been asked for the drilling of a new one). Equipment for the most part is very old and has seen too many years of service - this mainly in the boy's and girl's wash rooms. The old tin wash troughs are eaten out and leaking and should be replaced with wash bowls. Some toilets have just recently been replaced, but many others will have to be scrapped - and soon.

We appreciate that a great many of these things cannot be secured - and we shall have to make haste slowly, but the Staff are working under many difficulties at the present time and it is hoped that many of the improvements and replacements suggested in this letter can be effected soon.

Seasonal repairs and improvements, such as painting, will be requested during the proper season.

We would also like to point out at this time that this School hopes to have a new classroom block ready for occupancy by next September, and if this becomes a reality the school attendance will increase enormously - making it all the more essential that the improvements asked for are installed.

R.D. Hogan,
Superintendent.

I am returning your requisition which you forwarded last July for equipment for the classroom block at the St. Paul's Indian Residential School. We did not order the articles last July, as we felt they should not be supplied until the building was nearly completed.

Our reason for returning this requisition is due to the fact that we consider the quantities of the different articles requested are in many cases excessive. For instance, why does the school request 10 looms? Unless you feel it is necessary to supply an electric floor polisher to both the St. Paul's and Blood Residential Schools, we do not feel that this item of equipment should be supplied to the St. Paul's Residential School.

It is not our custom to supply blankets, bedspreads, sheets and quilts except when a residential school first opens. Replacement of such articles is made by the school management. There has been no increase in the pupilage at the St. Paul's School, and consequently, we do not feel prepared to supply the articles listed under the heading "Dormitories", unless there is some reason why special consideration should be given.

What has been stated regarding the items under the heading "Dormitories" applies also to the items listed under the heading "Dining Room".
With reference to the 80 desks requested, we would like to know the sizes required, namely the number of large, medium and small desks. Are the desks presently in use in the classroom completely worn out?

I have your letter of the 20th instant, file 764-5 (E.1) regarding painting of the interior of the St. Paul's Residential School, Blood Reserve.

Re: St. Paul's Residential School.

I have your letter of the 15th instant, file 764-5 (E.1) regarding furnishings for the Principal's residence at the above school.

The present Principal of this school claims that the basement is so far removed from the boiler room that no heat is obtained and that a heating stove is necessary. After looking the situation over, I rather doubt that a heating stove is necessary and would leave this equipment in abeyance for the time being until the new Principal moves in. If a heater were supplied, it would be an ordinary tall coal heater, medium size.

As regards the cook stove, an average size cook stove should be supplied, coal burning. Archdeacon Middleton now has an electric cook stove installed in the kitchen which he is willing to sell for $100.00. This stove is already hooked up to the Calgary Power line and is in very good condition. Here again, however, as in all the furnishings for the Principal's residence, I hesitate to make any recommendations as the new Principal's tastes may be far different from mine; I would suggest that he be allowed to make his own decision as regards the cook stove.

The measurements of the dining room are 15 x 24 and the sitting room are 15 x 27 and 25 yards of stair carpeting are needed.

We are glad to see that local purchase of curtain material is allowed and it would seem to me to be much more satisfactory for the incoming Principal, if he were allowed also to choose his carpeting, cook stove, and, in fact, all furniture.; I am sure that with the Government discounts we receive we can do as well in purchasing as anyone.

(R.D. Ragan)
Superintendent.

Please be advised that Mr. Pitts reported to this office for duty as Principal of the above School on the first instant and we were certainly pleased to see him. Although advised that the residence at the St. Paul's School must be vacated by the first of August, Archdeacon Middleton is still in residence at this writing, which makes it awkward for Mr. Pitts and family; he has faithfully promised, however, to vacate by the end of this week.

Further to my letter of the 29th July, even file, regarding the cook stove and measurements of the dining and sitting rooms, I now wish to report further. Archdeacon Middleton gave me the measurements of the dining room as $15' \times 24'$ and the sitting room as $15' \times 27'$; when Mr. Pitts checked these measurements, however, he has found that both rooms are, according to him, $12' \times 18'$; therefore the size of the carpets will be substantially different than previously reported.

As previously stated, it would be so much more satisfactory if the Department could allow the Pitts' to choose their own furnishings under my supervision, and getting Government discount, submitting all prices and descriptions to the Department before any actual purchases were made. (R.D. Ragam)

The cooler should be insulated with 6" of Fiberglas insulation in all walls, ceiling and floor, and to maintain a 36 - 38° temperature, with a product load of approximately 500 lbs. per day, we would suggest the following Frigidaire equipment:

1 - Model CAK75T heavy-duty air-cooled Frigidaire Compressor unit.
1 - Model CO620 heavy-duty Blower type cooling unit.

To properly insulate the cooler would require approximately 575 sq. ft. of 6" Fiberglas; 1 roll Vapor-proof Paper; 1 gallon Asphalt; 1 - either 2'6" or 3'5" x 6'6" refrigerator door; 2- 30" x 30" service doors for the side wall of the cooler.

The supply on the installation of the above equipment and material, but assuming that the actual construction of the cabinet and walk-in cooler would be made on the premises, with us supplying the required insulation, would be $1,057.00 F.O.B. Cardston.

For your information we have this equipment in stock and could supply the insulation when required, and the Frigidaire equipment when installation and insulation of the cooler had been completed.

The price quoted does not include the electrical wiring of which we are not aware as to what would be
required, but this could be done locally.

Re: Walk-In Refrigerator, St. Paul's Residential School.

You will recall that a walk-in refrigerator is badly needed at the St. Paul's Residential School and installation of this equipment was put over from the last fiscal year until this fiscal year. Mr. D.L. Pitts, who recently took over as Principal of this School, now informs me that the Department are ready to go ahead with the installation of this important equipment.

We have, therefore, had a refrigerator expert from the Bruce Robinson Electric Co., Calgary, inspect the School and give us his recommendations and prices; copy of which is enclosed. This walk-in cooler is to be installed inside the School proper, between the kitchen and the milk room in what is now a storeroom; this will make a very convenient arrangement. We have asked Mr. Tom Weston, Contractor of Cardston, to give us an estimate on building this refrigerator room according to the Bruce Robinson Electric Company's specifications; copy of this also attached. This would make the complete cost of the cabinet and walk-in cooler, including the installation and supplying of the frigidaire equipment, etc., not including the electrical wiring $2,395.60.

It is respectfully recommended that the enclosed two tenders be accepted as quickly as possible so that the St. Paul's School might have refrigeration at the earliest possible moment.

(R.D. Ragan)
Superintendent

Dear Colonel Neary:

This is to offer my sincere apologies for that rather hasty phone call of yesterday morning.

We were so disappointed at the list of furniture that we noted was dated August 18th and which we thought was in reply to our urgent request for the furniture for our house.

Mr. Ragan told us that you had been out of the office and we assumed that possibly some clerk not familiar with the situation had undertaken to equip a small day school teacherage.

Immediately after the phone call we received a letter from Canon Cook in which he stated that you had purchased very generously for our residence. Your own reassurance over the phone gave me considerable encouragement.

Realizing the heavy expense, we had been careful to choose with an eye to cost and Eaton's had offered us bargains over and above the Sale Prices. The residence is an 8-roomed house, but because of the expense, we had planned on leaving two rooms very sketchy. When we went to Kenora we were faced with a similar situation, and at that time we proceeded in the same manner as this time.

We find that the Staff rooms are very poorly furnished, (partly due to the fact that the existing furniture must be spread more thinly among an increasing Staff) and we wonder if this first order can be used in the main school and the new school block, to help out that situation?

We have always appreciated your sympathetic understanding in the past, and hope that we are still on the old friendly basis.

Sincerely,

Dear Sir: Re: Wiring in St. Paul's and St. Mary's Indian Schools

An inspection was made of the electrical installations at St. Paul's and St. Mary's Indian Schools on September 15th 1948. I am sorry I did not have the opportunity of discussing these installations with you at the time of my visit as your office was locked each time I called.

These installations, since first being made, have had additional loads connected and the present services are overloaded. The method used for wiring the main buildings is conductors run with present requirements, with the exception that all neutrals are fused, and circuits are badly over-fused. Considerable use has been made of extension cord to secure additional outlets and this creates a fire hazard as well as personal hazard.

The distribution panel in the St. Paul's School and the main switch board in the St. Mary's School are of the open terminal type with exposed live connections when changing fuses or operating starters. The outside and wiring in each case should be overhauled to provide adequate clearance between conductors, from ground, and over buildings, and decayed and undersized poles replaced to restore the distribution to a safe condition.

The following corrections were felt advisable in the interests of safety and are listed under the name of the School to which they apply:

ST. PAUL'S SCHOOL:
1. Increase the service entrance conductors and conduit to a minimum of 225 amps. capacity, with a #2 gauge wire run to the water line. This will require No. 4-0 wire in #2 conduit. The service must be located in an accessible location so that it will not be necessary to stand on the meter to operate switches or work on equipment.
2. Remove all fuses from neutrals.

Re: 19th Sept., 1949.

ST. PAUL'S SCHOOL - Cont'd

3. Check existing lighting and receptacle branch circuits to limit the load per circuit to not more than 15 amps., and reduce the fuses in these circuits to not more than 15 amps. This may require installation of additional circuits to remove excess loads from present circuits. It is recommended the open terminal panel be replaced with a dead front panel.

4. Remove extension cords used as permanent wiring or replace with approved wiring in conduit or metal moulding.

5. Install separate circuits for the irons in the laundry. These outlets to be equipped with an indicating switch and pilot lamp.

6. Rewire in conduit the line from the outlet box in the machine room to the pump motor in the pump room.

7. Outgoing feeds from the building to the yard distribution to have at least 8 ft. of clearance over the garage roof and 12" between conductors.

8. Provide fuse protection and a ground at the horse barn.

9. Change service into the cow barn to 250 volts, installing a ground and providing a separate circuit for the 1 H.P. motor and another circuit for lighting. This barn is wired with BX cable which is not approved for damp locations and should be replaced with knob and tube wiring using solid knobs.

10. Rewire the chicken house with knob and tube wiring, installing fuse protection at entrance.

ST. MATTHEW'S SCHOOL:

1. Increase the present service entrance to a minimum of 275 amps. capacity, running a ground wire of #2 gauge to the water line and install a gutter at the distribution centre.

2. Install switches or pull fuse panel to provide adequate protection for the various circuits and feeders.

3. Replace live front switch board with a dead front panel or switches.

4. Remove fuses from all neutral conductors.

5. Check existing lighting and receptacle branch circuits to limit the load per circuit to not more than 15 amps., and reduce the fuses in these circuits to not more than 15 amps.

6. Rewire the garage using approved wiring methods and properly supporting the service drop to this building so as to clear the overhead pipe from the water tower to the School.

Re: Power Lines

Dear Mr. Ragan:

On Wednesday afternoon October 25th, Cooper's large truck loaded with beds, mattresses, etc., touched one of our overhead power lines and pulled over one of the posts, dropping the lines down to the ground.

This created a serious condition in the boys' playground and we had to cut off the power at the main switch.

Therefore, it was necessary to call out an electrician to repair our wires to give service to the school. This was fortunately assisted by the use of the large truck and gin poles of Mr. Naughan, the well driller who placed our new poles into their prepared holes.

It was this condition and danger which has been prompting us for some time to have the wires raised to a proper level. We still have 220 volt wiring just eight feet above the boys' playground which is a temptation for them to touch the wires.

We again request that you will draw this danger to the attention of the Department so that the recommendations recently made by the electrical inspector may be speedily carried out.

May we also request permission to forward to the Department for payment the account of the electrician for this emergency repair job?

BUILDING CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE

Kitchen and storerooms should be of a non-absorbent material and painted with enamel so that surfaces may be washed.

EQUIPMENT

The dining room tables are in poor repair, that is, warped. New tables covered with a non-absorbent material are recommended. A kitchen work table also requires covering.

DISHES AND UTENSILS

There are a number of cracked and chipped cups.

CLEANING AND STERILIZING OF DISHES AND UTENSILS

Dishwashing facilities are considered inadequate. A three compartment sink and drainboards of a non-corrodible material are recommended to meet Provincial standards. The first sink is used to wash, second to rinse and the third to sterilize with a chlorine or quaternary ammonium compound.

FOOD STORAGE

There is signs of mice in the storeroom.

REFRIGERATION

Refrigeration is inadequate and results in open displays of food i.e., butter, cooked meat, vegetables, etc. An attempt has been made to keep these foods cool in the dairy room, which although it is cooler than adjoining rooms still does not refrigerate food and is most unsuitable from a public health viewpoint.

TOILETS AND WASHROOMS

Some toilet seats are needed and it is understood that improved hand washing facilities are soon to be installed.

The present metal covered wooden table is in an unsanitary condition due to the corrosion and rusting away of the metal, thus allowing water to penetrate beneath it. The present enamel handbasins are badly chipped and cannot be kept clean.

GARBAGE

More metal covered receptacles are required for proper disposal.
St. Paul's Report Contd.

MISCELLANEOUS

There is a fairly heavy infestation of cockroaches in the kitchen and laundry room. An insecticide and powder is being used.

THE BAKESHOP

Is generally clean, but it was noted that the wooden lids of the troughs used for storage of bread are in a very poor state of repair and cannot be kept clean. Also, the present arrangement used for the mixing of bread i.e., a series of wash tubs in which the dough is kneaded by the youngsters cannot be regarded as a good method of handling. A mixer is recommended.

The dairy room requires simple racks for the storage of pails and utensils. A small pipe or 2" x 2" is easily kept clean. A few pails are corroded.

Cooling of milk to 50° immediately after milking is essential to good quality. This may be done by the use of the water cooled can plunger method or immersion in a tank of cold water.

The sterilizing of dairy utensils with a chlorine rinse is advocated, as in the washing of the cows udders prior to milking.

(Signed)

J.E. Hoskins
Sanitary Inspector.

Re: St. Paul's School

I wish to report that the Hot Water System in the Classroom Block at the St. Paul's Residential School was frozen on the night of January 1st, and radiators and pipes have frozen and burst.

As Monday, January 2nd was a holiday, this could not be reported to you and up to the present time today (11:30 a.m.) no telephone communication to Calgary is possible, but the following wire has been forwarded to you:

No telephone but must report radiators and pipe frozen and burst
St. Paul's Classroom Block on second (Stop) Have called plumbers as emergency will report further when phone lines clear.

It appears that Mr. Patterson, the Night Watchman, was given four days holiday over the New Year, and other staff were covering his duties. Mr. D. S. Pitts, Principal, reports that he inspected the boiler in the Classroom Block at 11:00 p.m. and fired it up and Tom Prairie Chicken, an Indian, was to fire up at 4:00 a.m. At 7:00 a.m. when another man came on duty the fire was very low, and the pipe in the tunnel connecting the School and the Classroom Block had frozen and burst. There was no heat in the radiators and no circulation, and it was impossible with no water to bring any heat into the building. Hall Brothers, Plumbers at Cardston, were called but were out with another frozen pipe job and had worked all night the night before and could not come. Therefore Mr. J. C. Edgar, Plumbers of Macleod were called and appeared at the school with two helpers on the afternoon of the 2nd instant. All available staff at the school had worked up to this time changing pipes and trying to save other radiators from freezing, but
Would you kindly bring these matters to the attention of the Department as soon as possible? We should especially like to have the large Fire Extinguishers, Alarm Bells, and outside Hose for this Fall Term.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Supt. Ragan:

Re: Fire Equipment

As discussed with you during visit of inspection to the school on Monday, August 15th, herewith we request the following equipment as absolutely essential immediately for Fire Protection in St. Paul's School.

As mutually agreed, further additions of inside hose would not be of much value since our water supply and water pressure could not handle more than one outlet at one time.

However, we both feel that it is essential that the School be supplied with the large 2½ gallon Soda and Acid type extinguisher. We require eleven (11) of this type to take care of 2 on each floor, and 1 each in Furnace Room, Kitchen, and Garage.

Of secondary importance would be three (3) of the Pyrene type. One for each the shop, barn, and tractor shed. I say 'secondary', because the small type at present supplied could be used in these places.

We also need at least 500 feet of rubber lined outside hose of standard 1½" couplings.

The alarm Bell system at present installed is not satisfactory, in that it can only be heard on the main floor. I would strongly recommend that two more Fire Alarm Bells of 10" Diam. be purchased to install one on each side main building, upper floor. These could be connected with the present Alarm buttons so that all three could be rung from various floors by pressing any one button.

Re Fire Escape. These are at present unsatisfactory in that (a) they must be entered through Staff Bedrooms, which are often kept locked, and (b) they follow the HERRICK stairwells. In case of fire the natural exit would be down the other stairway, rather than the fire escape. The entrances to fire escapes, should be from the dormitories. At present the Fire Escapes end on the roof of the Entrances, about 12' above the ground. Merely placing a ladder here would only assist unwanted night visitors. There should be a balanced steel ladder, counter-weighted.

with no heat and the temperature outside 35 degrees below zero, this was practically impossible. As January 2nd was a statutory holiday, your office could not be contacted for authority to call in the Plumbers and it is hoped this action is approved.

I have just returned from the School where the Plumbers have worked all night and now have some heat in the building (the temperature last night was 45 degrees below zero). It now appears that 100 sections of radiator is going to be required as well as about 25 ft. of 1 inch pipe and one toilet bowl which was broken - this material we estimate will come to approximately $400.00. We have had up to five Plumbers working and although it is very hard to say what their wages and transportation will come to we would estimate that another $250.00 will be required for wages. It is our intention to telephone your office and request that authority for $650.00 be requested by teletype from Ottawa.

As to the cause of this freezing, it would seem to me that it could be laid to three things:

1. The Principal in order to conserve coal while the pupils were out on holiday had shut off every third radiator; with Hot Water System, we are quite sure that this should not have been done.

2. The main water pipe feeding the boiler which came through the tunnel between the school and classroom block froze and burst thereby cutting all the water supply for the boiler.

3. We very much doubt if Tom Prairie Chicken fired the classroom block boiler as ordered at 4:00 a.m., January 2nd.

Yours very truly,

I have your letter of December 27th, File 103/G-1-2, regarding the above. We have discussed the question of a Bread Mixer in the St. Paul's school with Mr. Pitts, principal, and as this school uses over 3000 loaves of bread each month, Mr. Pitts states that it would be much more economical for this school to make their own bread. He also states that it has been found by experiment and trials that it is cheaper to buy bread if using less than 2000 loaves of bread a month, but cheaper to make bread if over this amount. Added to this would be the necessity of picking up boughten bread every other day or so, which with winter roads and conditions as they are here, would be uncertain. The St. Paul's school have had a new oven installed last year, and it would seem that this should be used.

Therefore, it is our opinion that the St. Paul's school should make their bread and as suggested by the Superintendent of Education, Mr. Pitts will call at your office the next time he is in Calgary, so that some Bread Mixing Machine Company can be interviewed.

Re St.Pauls Indian School,Blood Reserve,Pumping System

Gentlemen:

With reference to the pumping system freezing in the above school we have examined this situation and find that there exists a serious situation for the bldg.,which has the pumping system and is part garage which is set over the pressure tank,is so poorly constructed and without any insulation,and in addition has no heat.The pump itself has an enclosure around it with an oil stove set alongside,which has kept the pump itself from freezing,but from the pump the discharge piping runs under the floor to the pressure tank,which is set under ground and under the Garage floor,the front of the tank is set in a basement or chamber in which the controls for pumping operation is placed,and there is cold air coming into this chamber which freezes these controls.We also noted that a hole has been made from this chamber into the boiler room,presuming it could be heated from the boiler room.but the opposite is the case,for there is a distinct draft which brings the cold air from the Garage thro,and past the controls into the boiler room,thereby setting up a draft,and which is really worse than if there was no opening,of course if all cracks which leak this cold air were stopped and the opening into the boiler room enlarged to a size of say a door then it would be a part of the boiler room.

Under these circumstances we could not recommend that a radiator or other steam heating,be used for we feel sure that they would freeze up during such times as the pressure dropped in the system,so the only thing we could suggest is that this bldg.( combined pump house & Garage be insulated and properly finished to make a properly built bldg.and then heated either with a stove or it may be done with a Steam Unit Heater from the heating system,

With reference to a steam unit heater.the cost of this would be for a 400 sq.ft Unit Heater complete with Thermostat Trap & valves together with the necessary piping to the system to make a complete job for the sum of $375.00 Three hundred and Seventy Five dollars,but the bldg would require to be fixed up properly before it could be used.

With reference to the cost of a check valve being installed to replace that which is worn out and using a standard 12"Swing Check this will cost with proper connections $55.00 Fifty Five dollars.

Trusting this is the information you require we are yours very truly

Re: St. Paul's School - Blood Reserve

During the very severe cold weather here we have been having trouble with the water system freezing at the above school, and I have had Hall Brother, Plumbers, look this situation over with a view to remedying same.

We attach hereto their letter which is self-explanatory regarding the cause of this freezing and their recommendations regarding having the combination Pump House and Garage properly insulated and heated to protect this water system. I have had Mr. T. E. Newton give me a tender on the costs of properly insulating and finishing this combination Garage Pump House and his tender in the amount of $664.00 is attached hereto.

At the present time gasoline torches are being used to try and prevent the pressure tank and water system from freezing, which is most unsatisfactory, and as this is an urgent situation we ask that the sum of $739.00 be authorized to insulate and heat the building housing the pressure tank and pumping system before other serious situations arise.

R. D. Ragan,

Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: St. Paul's School, Blood Reserve.

Further to my letter of the 3rd instant, I now wish to make a further report on the frozen heating system at the above school, on which you approved an expenditure of $650.00 by wire dated January 4th.

This system is now fully repaired and children are back into the classrooms. The cost of repairing, however, is going to run about $250.00 more than first anticipated. This is due to many more radiator sections being cracked than first estimated; these cracks were not visible and were only found after water was turned into the system. I now have J. C. Elgar and Sons, Plumbers, bill which amounts to $183.65; this will be vouchered for payment immediately. I have not as yet received Hall Brothers account, the Plumbers which secured the new sections, but they have estimated that their bill will amount to $725.00; this will be vouchered as soon as received.

Mr. Gooderham was with me on an inspection of the two schools on this reserve on the 11th and 12th instant, and he was shown where heat must be gotten into the connecting tunnels to the classroom blocks at each school to prevent the pipes in these tunnels from freezing, thereby causing a repetition of what we have just gone through.

Hall Brothers, Plumbers of Cardston, have been asked to give a firm tender on installing heat in each of these tunnels and when this tender is received it will be forwarded for your further study through Mr. Gooderham's office.
It is hoped that a further $250.00 expenditure on the St. Paul's heating system can be approved.

R. D. Logan,
Superintendent,
Blood Indian Reserve.

Re: St. Paul's Indian Residential School.

I have your letter of the 27th of September file 764-5 (E1) regarding our voucher No. 345 in the amount of $1,524.58 for painting of the above school.

It is much regretted that a misunderstanding in this case has occurred. In our defense we must say that we believe we received the best value for the money spent that could possibly be obtained - all paint was of first quality and supplied at wholesale prices. The painting work itself was also of first quality and of a greater quantity than could be secured on any "quotation". Work was all completed before school opened and the pupils returned to a much more cheerful atmosphere than if the painting had not been done.

On receipt of your letter of June 4th we thought it good business then not to proceed with the painting at this school as Archdeacon Middleton was due to retire at the end of July and certainly the incoming principal should be allowed to see what part of the whole school, which is badly in disrepair, should be painted. Consequently we waited until Mr. Pitts the new Principal arrived, told him what money was allocated for painting and asked him to choose those areas which, in his opinion, were most in need of paint. After Mr. Pitts arrival there was not time before school opening to submit another tender and as $1,500.00 had been allocated for painting, we thought it unnecessary.

In view of Colonel Neary's wish that this school be put back on its feet as soon as possible and in order that Mr. Pitts might receive some encouragement from the set-back he received when first viewing the school we took it upon ourselves as Superintendent to get this work done and we are sorry if we have overstepped our authority, but again we must say that a very good job has been done and this school is well on its way to recovery.

R.D. Regan,
Superintendent,
Blood Indian Reserve.

Your file 764-5 (E 1).

Your letter of September 27th addressed to Superintendent Ragan, copy to this office, was discussed with Mr. Ragan when I was in Cardston yesterday. I feel that no useful purpose will be served by endeavoring to go into great length regarding the many difficulties and responsibilities that Superintendent Ragan has had to cope with during the last two months, involving the harvest, cattle sales, etc., etc. I should tell you, however, that in the very midst of his busiest season of the year, he lost a clerk grade 3, an assistant agent grade 3 and a stenographer grade 2; these losses all came within two weeks of one another. He is still without the assistant and the stenographer.

Unable to give his personal attention to every matter and every problem arising on the reserve at this critical time, he was faced with the need of having the interior of the badly deteriorated St. Paul's Indian Residential School ready for occupancy at school opening. In his haste to take care of every pressing matter I can understand him considering your letter of June 4th authority to expend $1,500.00 for painting badly needed in this school.

I visited the school yesterday. Although there is still considerable work to be done to bring this school up to a decent standard, I was impressed by the good and sufficient value obtained for the $1,500.00 and I strongly urge that the account be passed for payment as soon as possible.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

You will recall that approval was given to a tender from the firm of H.J. Roelofs & Son, North Lethbridge Motors and Auto Wreckers, North Lethbridge, Alberta, for the moving of two buildings recently purchased from War Assets Corporation. The tender of this firm reads as follows:

"We herewith submit our tender to move and place on foundation on the Blood Indian Reserve on sites selected by the Superintendent, buildings as follows:

Building #12 located at Pearce not more than $1800.00
Building #38 located at Macleod not more than $2800.00

The above prices may be less depending on conditions of roads to be travelled."

We have now been advised by Regional Supervisor Gooderham that he recommends the cancellation of the Roelofs tender and the acceptance of another tender from Kaughman & Sons of Taber, Alberta. Their tender is attached hereto.

You will note that this firm will not only move the buildings, but will also restore the sites to the condition as called for by War Assets Corporation. They will also tie the buildings together which means the adding of another rafter, floor stud and wall stud and will fit the whole building into one unit. They will also place heating boilers where required, etc. Roelofs' tender does not include these items as he will only place the buildings on the foundation.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6373, file 764-5, part 10)

Mr. Roelofs was asked to quote on this work, but was only interested in moving the buildings as per his original tender.

Therefore, we are concurring in Regional Supervisor Gooderham's recommendation that Roelofs' tender be cancelled and that the work be given to Kaughman & Sons. Roelofs is not expecting this work and Kaughman & Sons are prepared to commence work immediately.
