Dear Sir,

While repairing the well pipe at St. Paul's School we noticed several bends in the pump pipe also several welds and very bad threads eaten away we had threads put on the worst, also the bent pipe is causing the wood rods to wear badly. The cylinder has been bored out & is off size now I was told. After installing it in the new well, the school found they could not get the tank pressure past 42 lbs., which not let the automatic switch shut off, which is 45 lbs.

We were then called back to find there trouble, which was (two) leaks in the pump pipe which they were unable to build up pressure.

I would like to suggest a new pump outfit, as they may have trouble any day.

Attention: Mr. B.F. Neary, Supt. of Education.

Reference your 103-1-5 (E.1) of the 30th of April with regard to the new well drilled at St. Paul's Residential School, Blood Reserve.

Herewith vouchers, in this connection, as follows:

No. 277 - $167.00 - Cleaning barn well; supplying new rod.
No. 278 - $689.50 - Drilling and casing new well.
No. 279 - $76.00 - Pulling pump on old well, installing on new well.
No. 298 - $37.50 - Plumber's charges re connecting pump to new well.

Total - $969.00

This is, we know, over the amount authorized, but costs were kept to a minimum, the school doing the concrete and carpentry work and helping with the other work.

Regarding the last paragraph of your letter as to whether or not the well can now be considered satisfactory, I am forced to answer in the negative. We have had a good deal of trouble with the well since drilled but at this writing seem to have it working satisfactorily although there is no guarantee how long this condition will exist. It was necessary to call Mr. Maughan, the driller, from Lethbridge on two different occasions when the well failed; on one trip he had to bring his equipment and pull the well - which he did at no cost to the Department. When the well was pulled it was found that the trouble was caused by leaks in the old pipes and that the cylinder was badly worn; however, the pipes were re-threaded where needed and again put in the well and everything has been fairly serene since. Mr. Maughan warned me, however, that the well might fail any day - he stated that the pipe was too old, that the rods were becoming badly worn due to the pipe being crooked and that the only permanent remedy was new pipe, rods and cylinder. I asked him to give me a full report with an estimate of the cost of replacement; this is attached. I am also enclosing Mr. Maughan's log of the new well for your information.

To add to our troubles on the water system at this school, the Provincial Boiler Inspector, Mr. W.A. Henry visited us to inspect pressure vessels. He found that the large water pressure tank installed by...
and Engineering Branch of the Department at Banff early in 1947 was buried deep in the ground and he could not inspect same. He stated that this was a pressure vessel carrying 80 lbs. pressure and has been installed contrary to all the laws and regulations regarding high pressure vessels, that it had to be inspected once each year and must be set on concrete trunnions in a concrete pit so that it could be inspected. This is the tank we had trouble with last September when it sank further in the clay soil shearing off the connecting pipes.

The new well, of course, had to be drilled outside the existing building and is now sitting out in the open without protection of any kind. A building will have to be erected over this and as it is near the pressure vessel, and if Mr. Henry is correct, one structure can be built to house both the pump and the pressure tank. Excavation and cement work would have to be done around the tank, and I would suggest that the building be constructed of cinder blocks and frame and shingle roof, approximately 24 x 30 feet. I am quite aware that this school has had their full share, and more, of improvements this fiscal year, but I see no alternative but to erect this building. If you concur in this I shall procure tenders and costs.

We hope that it will not be necessary to buy new pipe, rods and cylinder for sometime but this information is given at this time so that you may be aware of the situation. We would be pleased to have your comments on the whole situation.

R.D. Racan,
Superintendent.

C.C. G.H. Good rham, Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Calgary.

Andy Kaughman, head of Kaughman and Sons, who tendered on this moving, was killed last week in an automobile accident. The remaining son, L.W. Kaughman, finds himself in financial difficulties and has appealed to me for payment on account. This son assures me that he will carry on with the moving and carry out the original contract. I have agreed to pay him $2000.00 for work already done as these buildings are cut, jacked up and ready to move. The flood stage of the Belly River is the only thing holding up delivery and it is not expected that this river will be down to normal before another month, at least.

It is hoped that this payment can be made to L.W. Kaughman at this time.

(E.D. Ragan)
Superintendent.
